column3: infra: update link to groovy zip, as bintray is deprecated
column4: I took a link from  https://groovy.apache.org/download.html  ![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/812984/127756933-49b33ead-fbc7-4868-a0cb-6735153109c5.png)

I have recently upgraded Checkstyle from 8.20 to 8.39 and have noticed a behavior change that I did not see documented.  Maybe this was a bug that was fixed or is a new bug.  Here is my old definition (8.20): ```                                                                                                 ```  Here is my new definition (8.39): ```                                                               ```  The change is related to missing parameters:  My Javadoc looks as follows: ```     /**      * Create a component using this model.      *      * @param inModel      */  public Component(Model inModel) {         _model = inModel;     } ```  In 8.20 this would fail with Expected @param tag for 'inModel' [JavadocMethod]  In 8.39 is does not fail  If I add anything after the @param inModel in 8.20 then it passes.  This forced me to add (meaningful?) docs as in:      * @param inModel The model that will be used to save the world.       I thought this was a useful feature.  The thing is the check was satisfied even if I just add a single space after the parameter name.  So I don't know if this was a feature that went away or a bug that was fixed.  I preferred the old behavior.  Thanks, Michael

column3: OperatorWrap with token ASSIGN too strict for annotations
column4: I have read check documentation: https://checkstyle.sourceforge.io/config_whitespace.html#OperatorWrap I have downloaded the latest checkstyle from: https://checkstyle.org/cmdline.html#Download_and_Run I have executed the cli and showed it below, as cli describes the problem better than 1,000 words  ```bash /var/tmp $ javac OperatorWrapExample.java  /var/tmp $ cat config.xml                             /var/tmp $ cat OperatorWrapExample.java @Annotation(example = {         "foo",         "bar" }) public class OperatorWrapExample {      public String[] array = {             "foo",             "bar"     }; }  @interface Annotation {     String[] example(); }  /var/tmp $ RUN_LOCALE="-Duser.language=en -Duser.country=US" /var/tmp $ java $RUN_LOCALE -jar checkstyle-9.1-all.jar -c config.xml OperatorWrapExample.java Starting audit... [ERROR] I:\_tmp\_checkstyle\OperatorWrapExample.java:1:21: '=' should be on a new line. [OperatorWrap] Audit done. Checkstyle ends with 1 errors. ```  ---  In the above example, the array field allows the first element to be on a new line. If the same is done for an annotation, Checkstyle complains. The only way to "fix" this is to put the first element on the same line as the `= {`. I expect the same behaviour in annotations as in other code.

I have read check documentation: https://checkstyle.sourceforge.io/config_naming.html#AbbreviationAsWordInName I have downloaded the latest checkstyle from: https://checkstyle.org/cmdline.html#Download_and_Run I have executed the cli and showed it below, as cli describes the problem better than 1,000 words  ```bash /var/tmp $ javac TestABbreviation.java  /var/tmp $ cat config.xml                                                              /var/tmp $ cat TestABbreviation.java public class TestABbreviation {}  /var/tmp $ RUN_LOCALE="-Duser.language=en -Duser.country=US" /var/tmp $ java $RUN_LOCALE -jar checkstyle-9.0.1-all.jar -c config.xml TestABbreviation.java Starting audit... [WARN] /var/tmp/TestABbreviation.java:1:14: Abbreviation in name 'TestABbreviation' must contain no more than '1' consecutive capital letters. [AbbreviationAsWordInName] Audit done. ``` ---  Given that `allowedAbbreviations` is set to `AB`, I would expect the `TestABbreviation` name to be valid. It appears there is an off-by-one error in `AbbreviationAsWordInName` because setting `allowedAbbreviations` to `A` results in no warnings:   ```bash /var/tmp $ cat config.xml                                                              /var/tmp $ java $RUN_LOCALE -jar ./checkstyle-9.0.1-all.jar -c ./config.xml TestABbreviation.java Starting audit... Audit done. ```  Interestingly enough, if the abbreviation is at the end of the name, the check works as expected:  ```bash /var/tmp $ cat config.xml                                                              /var/tmp $ cat TestAB.java public class TestAB {}  /var/tmp $ java $RUN_LOCALE -jar ./checkstyle-9.0.1-all.jar -c ./config.xml TestABbreviation.java Starting audit... Audit done. ```

column3: StackOverflow Error in IndentationCheck on deeply concatenated strings
column4: I have read check documentation: https://checkstyle.sourceforge.io/config_misc.html#Indentation  Noticed at https://github.com/checkstyle/checkstyle/pull/9622#issuecomment-924361613:  ```bash  ➜  cat Test.java public class Test {     public void test() {         String s = " " + " " + " " + " " + " " + " " + " " + " " + " " + " " + " " + " " + " " +                 " " + " " + " " + " " + " " + " " + " " + " " + " " + " " + " " + " " + " " +                 " " + " " + " " + " " + " " + " " + " " + " " + " " + " " + " " + " " + " " + ...                 " " + " " + " " + " " + " " + " " + " " + " " + " " + " " + " " + " " + " " +                 " " + " " + " " + " " + " " + " " + " " + " " + " " + " " + " " + " " + " " +                 " " + " " + " " + " " + " " + " " + " " + " " + " " + " " + " " + " " + " " +                 " " + " " + " " + " " + " " + " " + " " + " " + " " + " " + " " + " " + " ";      } }  ➜  cat Test.java | wc -l         3028  ➜  cat config.xml                                            ➜  javac Test.java  ➜  java -jar checkstyle-9.0-all.jar -c config.xml Test.java Starting audit... Exception in thread "main" java.lang.Error: Error was thrown while processing Test.java         at com.puppycrawl.tools.checkstyle.Checker.processFiles(Checker.java:310)         at com.puppycrawl.tools.checkstyle.Checker.process(Checker.java:221)         at com.puppycrawl.tools.checkstyle.Main.runCheckstyle(Main.java:409)         at com.puppycrawl.tools.checkstyle.Main.runCli(Main.java:332)         at com.puppycrawl.tools.checkstyle.Main.execute(Main.java:191)         at com.puppycrawl.tools.checkstyle.Main.main(Main.java:126) Caused by: java.lang.StackOverflowError         at com.puppycrawl.tools.checkstyle.DetailAstImpl.getLineNo(DetailAstImpl.java:264)         at com.puppycrawl.tools.checkstyle.DetailAstImpl.findLineNo(DetailAstImpl.java:361)         at com.puppycrawl.tools.checkstyle.DetailAstImpl.getLineNo(DetailAstImpl.java:267)         at com.puppycrawl.tools.checkstyle.DetailAstImpl.findLineNo(DetailAstImpl.java:361)         at com.puppycrawl.tools.checkstyle.DetailAstImpl.getLineNo(DetailAstImpl.java:264)         at com.puppycrawl.tools.checkstyle.checks.indentation.AbstractExpressionHandler.getFirstAst(AbstractExpressionHandler.java:442)         at com.puppycrawl.tools.checkstyle.checks.indentation.AbstractExpressionHandler.getFirstAst(AbstractExpressionHandler.java:453)         at com.puppycrawl.tools.checkstyle.checks.indentation.AbstractExpressionHandler.getFirstAst(AbstractExpressionHandler.java:453)         at com.puppycrawl.tools.checkstyle.checks.indentation.AbstractExpressionHandler.getFirstAst(AbstractExpressionHandler.java:453)         at com.puppycrawl.tools.checkstyle.checks.indentation.AbstractExpressionHandler.getFirstAst(AbstractExpressionHandler.java:453)  ...  ```  IndentationCheck is failing on a large number of string concatenations, the culprit is recursive calls to `AbstractExpressionHandler#getFirstAst`:  https://github.com/checkstyle/checkstyle/blob/1ce8eea267305f00807620768887949cca220d76/src/main/java/com/puppycrawl/tools/checkstyle/checks/indentation/AbstractExpressionHandler.java#L453  Perhaps some iterative approach will provide better performance and solve this issue.

column3: ClassFanOutComplexity fails to count all classes in multicatch and implements clause, remove unused CheckUtil#createFullType method
column4: I have read check documentation: https://checkstyle.sourceforge.io/config_metrics.html#ClassFanOutComplexity I have downloaded the latest checkstyle from: https://checkstyle.org/cmdline.html#Download_and_Run I have executed the cli and showed it below, as cli describes the problem better than 1,000 words  ```  ➜  src javac Test.java Note: Test.java uses or overrides a deprecated API. Note: Recompile with -Xlint:deprecation for details.  ➜  src cat config.xml                                                ➜  src cat Test.java import java.io.File; import java.io.IOException; import java.io.InputStream; import java.util.EmptyStackException;  public class Test {     public static void main(String[] args) {         try {             System.out.println(args[7]);             File myFile = new File("myfile.txt"); // 1              InputStream stream = myFile.toURL().openStream(); // 2         } catch (IOException  | EmptyStackException e) { // 3,4          }     }  }  ➜  src java -jar checkstyle-8.43-all.jar -c config.xml Test.java Starting audit... [ERROR] /home/nick/Desktop/Tester/src/Test.java:6:1: Class Fan-Out Complexity is 3 (max allowed is 1). [ClassFanOutComplexity] Audit done. Checkstyle ends with 1 errors. ➜  src    ```  I would expect the "Class Fan-Out Complexity" to be 4.

column3: UnnecessaryParentheses too strict with combined && and ||
column4: I have read check documentation: https://checkstyle.sourceforge.io/config_coding.html#UnnecessaryParentheses I have downloaded the latest checkstyle from: https://checkstyle.org/cmdline.html#Download_and_Run I have executed the cli and showed it below, as cli describes the problem better than 1,000 words  ```bash /var/tmp $ javac UnnecessaryParenthesesExample.java  /var/tmp $ cat config.xml                 /var/tmp $ cat UnnecessaryParenthesesExample.java public class UnnecessaryParenthesesExample {      public static boolean foo(int x, int y) {         return (x == 0 && y > 0) || (x > 0 && y == 0);     }      public static void main(String... args) {         System.out.printf("x = 0, y = 0: %b%n", foo(0, 0));         System.out.printf("x = 0, y = 1: %b%n", foo(0, 1));         System.out.printf("x = 1, y = 0: %b%n", foo(1, 0));         System.out.printf("x = 1, y = 1: %b%n", foo(1, 1));     } }  /var/tmp $ RUN_LOCALE="-Duser.language=en -Duser.country=US" /var/tmp $ java $RUN_LOCALE -jar checkstyle-9.1-all.jar -c config.xml UnnecessaryParenthesesExample.java Starting audit... [ERROR] I:\_tmp\_checkstyle\UnnecessaryParenthesesExample.java:4:16: Unnecessary parentheses around expression. [UnnecessaryParentheses] [ERROR] I:\_tmp\_checkstyle\UnnecessaryParenthesesExample.java:4:37: Unnecessary parentheses around expression. [UnnecessaryParentheses] Audit done. Checkstyle ends with 2 errors. ```  ---  While technically these parentheses are indeed unnecessary (`LAND` has a higher precedence than `LOR`), it makes the intent more clear. I've only been able to disable this warning by removing `LAND` from the tokens, but then Checkstyle won't be strict enough.  For now I've been adding helper variables and methods to work around the issue, but it would be nice to at least allow some extra parentheses when combining `LAND` and `LOR`.

column3: SimplifyBooleanExpression: A false negative about ternary operator
column4: I have read check documentation: https://checkstyle.sourceforge.io/config_coding.html#SimplifyBooleanExpression I have downloaded the latest checkstyle from: https://checkstyle.org/cmdline.html#Download_and_Run I have executed the cli and showed it below, as cli describes the problem better than 1,000 words  ```bash /var/tmp $ javac Test.java /var/tmp $ cat config.xml                            /var/tmp $ cat Test.java public class Test {     public boolean fun() {         return false;     }     public boolean foo() {         boolean tag = fun() ? true : false;  // should report a warning here         // boolean tag = func() == true; // can be detected         return tag;     } }  /var/tmp $ RUN_LOCALE="-Duser.language=en -Duser.country=US" /var/tmp $ java $RUN_LOCALE -jar checkstyle-9.2-all.jar -c ./config.xml Test.java  #[[PLACE YOUR OUTPUT HERE]] Starting audit... Audit done. ``` --- **Describe what you expect in detail.** --- I have just found a false negative about the rule SimplifyBooleanExpression. Please refer to the below simplfied case. Here, I think `fun() ? true : false`  at line 6 is similar to `func() == true`. They all can be simplified into `func()`.

column3: Javadoc: Incorrect parsing of white space token as text
column4:
I have read check documentation: https://checkstyle.org/config_xxxxxx.html#NameOfAffectedCheck I have downloaded the latest checkstyle from: https://checkstyle.org/cmdline.html#Download_and_Run I have executed the cli and showed it below, as cli describes the problem better than 1,000 words  ``` $ javac Test1.java                                       $ cat Test1.java  public class Test1 {           /**    * {@link www.google.com}    */    void foo1() {} }  $ java -jar checkstyle-8.43-SNAPSHOT-all.jar -J Test1.java CLASS_DEF -> CLASS_DEF [1:0] |--MODIFIERS -> MODIFIERS [1:0] |   `--LITERAL_PUBLIC -> public [1:0] |--LITERAL_CLASS -> class [1:7] |--IDENT -> Test1 [1:13] `--OBJBLOCK -> OBJBLOCK [1:19]     |--LCURLY -> { [1:19]     |--METHOD_DEF -> METHOD_DEF [6:3]     |   |--MODIFIERS -> MODIFIERS [6:3]     |   |--TYPE -> TYPE [6:3]     |   |   |--BLOCK_COMMENT_BEGIN -> /* [3:2]     |   |   |   |--COMMENT_CONTENT -> *
   * {@link www.google.com}
    [3:4]     |   |   |   |   `--JAVADOC -> JAVADOC [3:5]     |   |   |   |       |--NEWLINE -> 
 [3:5]     |   |   |   |       |--LEADING_ASTERISK ->    * [4:0]     |   |   |   |       |--TEXT ->   [4:4]                                 // Error,  Expected WS-> [4:4]     |   |   |   |       |--JAVADOC_INLINE_TAG -> JAVADOC_INLINE_TAG [4:5]     |   |   |   |       |   |--JAVADOC_INLINE_TAG_START -> { [4:5]     |   |   |   |       |   |--LINK_LITERAL -> @link [4:6]     |   |   |   |       |   |--WS ->   [4:11]     |   |   |   |       |   |--REFERENCE -> REFERENCE [4:12]     |   |   |   |       |   |   `--PACKAGE_CLASS -> www.google.com [4:12]     |   |   |   |       |   `--JAVADOC_INLINE_TAG_END -> } [4:26]     |   |   |   |       |--NEWLINE -> 
 [4:27]     |   |   |   |       |--TEXT ->     [5:0]     |   |   |   |       `--EOF ->  [5:3]     |   |   |   `--BLOCK_COMMENT_END -> */ [5:3]     |   |   `--LITERAL_VOID -> void [6:3]     |   |--IDENT -> foo1 [6:8]     |   |--LPAREN -> ( [6:12]     |   |--PARAMETERS -> PARAMETERS [6:13]     |   |--RPAREN -> ) [6:13]     |   `--SLIST -> { [6:15]     |       `--RCURLY -> } [6:16]     `--RCURLY -> } [7:0] ``` ---  Expected White Space Token  This parsing is done correctly for others. Eg:  For  ```   /**    * @code Something.    */    void foo1() {} ```  AST:  ```     |   |   |--BLOCK_COMMENT_BEGIN -> /* [3:2]     |   |   |   |--COMMENT_CONTENT -> *
   * @code Something.
    [3:4]     |   |   |   |   `--JAVADOC -> JAVADOC [3:5]     |   |   |   |       |--NEWLINE -> 
 [3:5]     |   |   |   |       |--LEADING_ASTERISK ->    * [4:0]     |   |   |   |       |--WS ->   [4:4]     |   |   |   |       |--JAVADOC_TAG -> JAVADOC_TAG [4:5]     |   |   |   |       |   |--CUSTOM_NAME -> @code [4:5]     |   |   |   |       |   |--WS ->   [4:10]     |   |   |   |       |   `--DESCRIPTION -> DESCRIPTION [4:11]     |   |   |   |       |       |--TEXT -> Something. [4:11]     |   |   |   |       |       |--NEWLINE -> 
 [4:21]     |   |   |   |       |       `--TEXT ->     [5:0]     |   |   |   |       `--EOF ->  [5:3]     |   |   |   `--BLOCK_COMMENT_END -> */ [5:3] ```

column3: WhitespaceAround should enforce whitespace around empty blocks
column4: I have read check documentation: https://checkstyle.org/config_whitespace.html#WhitespaceAround  ```bash $ javac --verbose --enable-preview --source=17 TestClass.java [parsing started SimpleFileObject[TestClass.java]] [parsing completed 22ms]  $ cat config.xml ``` ```xml                                                                                                               ``` ```bash $ cat TestClass.java ``` ```java public class TestClass{                                                      // OK   TestClass c = new TestClass(){};                                           // Expected violation   TestClass(){}                                                              // OK, fixed in #8237   void method(){}                                                            // Expected violation   class Class{}                                                              // Expected violation   interface Interface{}                                                      // Expected violation   @interface Annotation{}                                                    // Expected violation   enum Enum{}                                                                // Expected violation   record Record(){}                                                          // Expected violation   public static void main(String... args){                                   // OK     boolean b = System.currentTimeMillis() < 0;     while (b){}                                                              // Expected violation     for (int i = 1; i > 1; i++){}                                            // Expected violation     do{} while (b);                                                          // OK     Runnable noop = () ->{};                                                 // OK   }   static{}                                                                   // Expected ONE violation   record Record2(String str){                                                // OK     public Record2{}                                                         // OK   } } ``` ```bash $ RUN_LOCALE="-Duser.language=en -Duser.country=US" $ java $RUN_LOCALE -jar checkstyle-9.0-all.jar -c config.xml TestClass.java Starting audit... [ERROR] TestClass.java:1:23: '{' is not preceded with whitespace. [WhitespaceAround] [ERROR] TestClass.java:3:14: '{' is not preceded with whitespace. [WhitespaceAround] [ERROR] TestClass.java:10:42: '{' is not preceded with whitespace. [WhitespaceAround] [ERROR] TestClass.java:14:5: 'do' is not followed by whitespace. [WhitespaceAround] [ERROR] TestClass.java:15:24: '->' is not followed by whitespace. [WhitespaceAround] [ERROR] TestClass.java:17:9: '{' is not followed by whitespace. [WhitespaceAround] [ERROR] TestClass.java:17:9: '{' is not preceded with whitespace. [WhitespaceAround] [ERROR] TestClass.java:17:10: '}' is not preceded with whitespace. [WhitespaceAround] Audit done. ``` --- There should be 9 more violations. Issue #8237 fixes only ctors. There should be only one violation on the line 17.

column3: Version 9.x Reports Whitespace Before Paren After String with Emojis
column4: I have read check documentation: https://checkstyle.org/config_whitespace.html#ParenPad I have downloaded the latest checkstyle from: https://checkstyle.org/cmdline.html#Download_and_Run I have executed the cli and showed it below, as cli describes the problem better than 1,000 words  ```bash /var/tmp $ javac Test.java  /var/tmp $ cat config.xml                 /var/tmp $ cat Test.java public class Test {     void emojiFamilyRunner(Consumer testRunner, String text) {         testRunner.accept("👩‍👩‍👧‍👧 " + text); // count as 12 units     }      void emojiFamilyWithSkinToneModifierRunner(Consumer testRunner, String text) {         testRunner.accept("👩🏻‍👩🏽‍👧🏾‍👦🏿 " + text); // count as 20 units     } }  /var/tmp $ RUN_LOCALE="-Duser.language=en -Duser.country=US" /var/tmp $ java $RUN_LOCALE -jar checkstyle-9.2-all.jar -c config.xml Test.java Starting audit... [ERROR] C:\Users\Work\Documents\Playground\CheckstylePlayground\.\src\main\java\Test.java:8:44: ')' is preceded with whitespace. [ParenPad] [ERROR] C:\Users\Work\Documents\Playground\CheckstylePlayground\.\src\main\java\Test.java:12:48: ')' is preceded with whitespace. [ParenPad] Audit done. ```  For Windows users, please use `type` instead of `cat` and run  ```cmd set RUN_LOCALE="-Duser.language=en -Duser.country=US" java %RUN_LOCALE% -jar checkstyle-9.2-all.jar -c config.xml Test.java ```  in place of the last 2 commands above.  ---  I would have expected no errors to be reported in this case but it appears the emoji messes up with where the paren is being seen. This doesn't occur when using 8.45.1.  This appears to be similar to https://github.com/checkstyle/checkstyle/issues/10920.

column3: Version 9.x reports NoWhitespaceBefore error on semicolon or comma after string with emoji
column4: I have read check documentation: https://checkstyle.org/config_whitespace.html#NoWhitespaceBefore I have downloaded the latest checkstyle from: https://checkstyle.org/cmdline.html#Download_and_Run I have executed the cli and showed it below, as cli describes the problem better than 1,000 words  ```bash /var/tmp $ javac Test.java  /var/tmp $ cat config.xml                         /var/tmp $ cat Test.java public class Test {     private String[] _mVar0 = {         "😃😉🙈" ,  // should be error         "😃 😉 🙈" ,  // should be error         "😃 😉 🙈",  // should ok         "😃😉🙈"  // should be ok     };     private String _mVar1 = "😃😉🙈"; // should be ok     private String _mVar2 = "😃 😉 🙈"; // should be ok     private String _mVar3 = "😃 😉 🙈" ; // should be error     private String _mVar4 = "a b c" ; // should be error }  /var/tmp $ RUN_LOCALE="-Duser.language=en -Duser.country=US" /var/tmp $ java $RUN_LOCALE -jar checkstyle-8.45.1-all.jar -c config.xml Test.java Starting audit... [ERROR] /home/jogchem/Projects/checkstyle/Test.java:3:18: ',' is preceded with whitespace. [NoWhitespaceBefore] [ERROR] /home/jogchem/Projects/checkstyle/Test.java:4:20: ',' is preceded with whitespace. [NoWhitespaceBefore] [ERROR] /home/jogchem/Projects/checkstyle/Test.java:10:40: ';' is preceded with whitespace. [NoWhitespaceBefore] [ERROR] /home/jogchem/Projects/checkstyle/Test.java:11:37: ';' is preceded with whitespace. [NoWhitespaceBefore] Audit done. Checkstyle ends with 4 errors.  /var/tmp $ java $RUN_LOCALE -jar checkstyle-9.1-all.jar -c config.xml Test.java Starting audit... [ERROR] /home/jogchem/Projects/checkstyle/Test.java:5:16: ',' is preceded with whitespace. [NoWhitespaceBefore] [ERROR] /home/jogchem/Projects/checkstyle/Test.java:9:36: ';' is preceded with whitespace. [NoWhitespaceBefore] [ERROR] /home/jogchem/Projects/checkstyle/Test.java:11:37: ';' is preceded with whitespace. [NoWhitespaceBefore] Audit done. Checkstyle ends with 3 errors. ```  For Windows users, please use `type` instead of `cat` and run  ```cmd set RUN_LOCALE="-Duser.language=en -Duser.country=US" java %RUN_LOCALE% -jar checkstyle-8.45.1-all.jar -c config.xml Test.java java %RUN_LOCALE% -jar checkstyle-9.1-all.jar -c config.xml Test.java ```  in place of the last 2 commands above.  ---  I expect the output of version 9.1 to be the same as for version 8.45.1, but instead it does not report errors for whitespace that follows a string with emoji. Even weirder is that I discovered this bug because it did report extra errors after upgrading to 9.1, so it seems that running the checkstyle from the maven plugin leads to different behaviour.  I've created a test case to reproduce this as well. I think the root cause of this issue is that ANTLR generates a different offset for the SEMI or COMMA token. Using the test file https://github.com/dijkstraj/checkstyle/blob/emoji-8/src/test/resources/com/puppycrawl/tools/checkstyle/grammar/InputAstRegressionEmojiString.java the generated AST (https://github.com/dijkstraj/checkstyle/blob/emoji-8/src/test/resources/com/puppycrawl/tools/checkstyle/grammar/InputAstRegressionEmojiString.txt) has columns 33 and 34 for the semicolons in version 8.45.1, but columns 31 and 34 in master (https://github.com/dijkstraj/checkstyle/blob/emoji-9/src/test/resources/com/puppycrawl/tools/checkstyle/grammar/InputAstRegressionEmojiString.txt). So it looks like a difference between character and byte offset.  The error that I originally ran into is reproducable with this line: https://github.com/dijkstraj/checkstyle/blob/emoji-9/src/test/resources/com/puppycrawl/tools/checkstyle/checks/whitespace/nowhitespacebefore/InputNoWhitespaceBeforeDefault.java#L309

column3: Record inside interface is treated as method
column4: I have read check documentation: https://checkstyle.org/config_naming.html#MethodName I have downloaded the latest checkstyle from: https://checkstyle.org/cmdline.html#Download_and_Run I have executed the cli and showed it below, as cli describes the problem better than 1,000 words  ```bash $ javac Test.java  $ cat Test.java public interface Test {   record MyRecord(int value) {}; }  $ cat config.xml                   $ RUN_LOCALE="-Duser.language=en -Duser.country=US" $ java $RUN_LOCALE -jar checkstyle-9.1-all.jar -c config.xml Test.java Starting audit... [ERROR] C:\Users\ebo\src\tmp\checkstyle-issue\Test.java:2:10: Name 'MyRecord' must match pattern '^[a-z][a-zA-Z0-9]*$'. [MethodName] Audit done. Checkstyle ends with 1 errors.  ```  ---  Expected no errors, but the name of the record is marked as an illegal method name.   If `interface Test` is replaced with `class Test` then the check goes through without errors.

column3: Inline @return tag does not pass SummaryJavadocCheck
column4: I have read check documentation: https://checkstyle.org/config_javadoc.html#SummaryJavadoc I have downloaded the latest checkstyle from: https://checkstyle.org/cmdline.html#Download_and_Run I have executed the cli and showed it below, as cli describes the problem better than 1,000 words  ```bash [octy@Draconnet JavaTesting]$ javac SummaryJavadocNewInlineReturn.java  [octy@Draconnet JavaTesting]$ cat config.xml                                        [octy@Draconnet JavaTesting]$ cat SummaryJavadocNewInlineReturn.java public class SummaryJavadocNewInlineReturn {     /**      * {@return a foo that is {@code 0}}      */     public int foo() {         return 0;     } } [octy@Draconnet JavaTesting]$ java -Duser.language=en -Duser.country=US -jar checkstyle-9.0-all.jar -c config.xml SummaryJavadocNewInlineReturn.java  Starting audit... [ERROR] /home/octy/Documents/JavaTesting/SummaryJavadocNewInlineReturn.java:2: Summary javadoc is missing. [SummaryJavadoc] Audit done. Checkstyle ends with 1 errors. ```  in place of the last 2 commands above.  ---  in JDK16+ The inline `{@return}` tag should pass `SummaryJavadocCheck` as it results in the following javadoc content: which includes the necessary period to pass the summary check.  ``` $ javadoc SummaryJavadocNewInlineReturn.java Loading source file SummaryJavadocNewInlineReturn.java... Constructing Javadoc information... Building index for all the packages and classes... Standard Doclet version 17.0.1+12-39 Building tree for all the packages and classes... Generating ./SummaryJavadocNewInlineReturn.html... SummaryJavadocNewInlineReturn.java:1: warning: no comment public class SummaryJavadocNewInlineReturn {        ^ Generating ./package-summary.html... Generating ./package-tree.html... Generating ./overview-tree.html... Building index for all classes... Generating ./allclasses-index.html... Generating ./allpackages-index.html... Generating ./index-all.html... Generating ./index.html... Generating ./help-doc.html... 1 warning ``` ![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/812984/147022460-ce7edf9d-1bbd-42b4-83bc-58902ee1596b.png)   in JDK11 such javadoc is not valid: ``` $ javadoc SummaryJavadocNewInlineReturn.java Loading source file SummaryJavadocNewInlineReturn.java... Constructing Javadoc information... Standard Doclet version 11 Building tree for all the packages and classes... Generating ./SummaryJavadocNewInlineReturn.html... SummaryJavadocNewInlineReturn.java:3: error: no tag name after @      * {@return a foo that is {@code 0}}        ^ SummaryJavadocNewInlineReturn.java:5: warning: no @return     public int foo() {  ```  **Note:** according to the [specs](https://docs.oracle.com/en/java/javase/16/docs/specs/javadoc/doc-comment-spec.html#return), the inline return tag is allowed only for methods.

column3: JavadocMethod accessModifiers incorrectly interpreted for interface class
column4: I have read check documentation: https://checkstyle.org/config_javadoc.html#JavadocMethod I have downloaded the latest checkstyle from: https://checkstyle.org/cmdline.html#Download_and_Run I have executed the cli and showed it below, as cli describes the problem better than 1,000 words  ```bash /var/tmp $ javac YOUR_FILE.java #[[MAKE SURE THERE IS SUCCESSFUL COMPILATION]] public interface MyInterface {   /** Javadoc ok here. */   void test();    class MyClass {     /** Missing parameter here. */     public MyClass(Integer amount) {     }   } }  /var/tmp $ cat config.xml                                                   /var/tmp $ cat YOUR_FILE.java #[[PLACE YOU OUTPUT HERE]]  /var/tmp $ RUN_LOCALE="-Duser.language=en -Duser.country=US" /var/tmp $ java $RUN_LOCALE -jar checkstyle-9.0-all.jar -c config.xml YOUR_FILE.java Starting audit... Audit done. ```` I expect checkstyle to report constructor to have missing javadoc param. Reason for that is that interface of this inner class is implicitly considered public according to java specs (Some IDEs even mark explicit public keyword as unnecessary). If I add public keyword to class declaration, constructor is reported by checkstyle as expected.

I have read check documentation: https://checkstyle.org/config_coding.html#MissingSwitchDefault I have downloaded the latest checkstyle from: https://checkstyle.org/cmdline.html#Download_and_Run I have executed the cli and showed it below, as cli describes the problem better than 1,000 words  ```bash /var/tmp $ javac Main.java #[[MAKE SURE THERE IS SUCCESSFUL COMPILATION]]  /var/tmp $ cat config.xml                   /var/tmp $ cat Main.java import java.nio.file.AccessMode;  public class Main {    private void createPlatform() {     String mode;     mode = switch (AccessMode.READ) {       case READ -> "1";       case WRITE -> "2";       case EXECUTE -> "3";     };   } }   /var/tmp $ RUN_LOCALE="-Duser.language=en -Duser.country=US" /var/tmp $ java $RUN_LOCALE -jar checkstyle-8.44-all.jar -c config.xml Main.java Starting audit... [ERROR] /home/gtx/Downloads/Main.java:7:12: switch without "default" clause. [MissingSwitchDefault] Audit done. Checkstyle ends with 1 errors. ``` **Expected**: no errors. Following code is very similar and does not produce any errors: ```java   private void createPlatform() {     String mode = switch (AccessMode.READ) {       case READ -> "1";       case WRITE -> "2";       case EXECUTE -> "3";     };   }    private String createPlatform() {     return switch (AccessMode.READ) {       case READ -> "1";       case WRITE -> "2";       case EXECUTE -> "3";     };   } ``` Given javac won't compile non-exhaustive switch, maybe `MissingSwitchDefault` check should be no-op for switch exceptions? Sample javac error: ```bash /var/tmp $ cat Main.java  import java.nio.file.AccessMode;  public class Main {    private String createPlatform() {     return switch (AccessMode.READ) {       case WRITE -> "2";       case EXECUTE -> "3";     };   } }  /var/tmp $ javac Main.java Main.java:6: error: the switch expression does not cover all possible input values     return switch (AccessMode.READ) {            ^ 1 error ```

column3: False positive for switch expressions in MissingSwitchDefault
column4: I have read check documentation: https://checkstyle.org/config_coding.html#MissingSwitchDefault  >Note that the compiler requires switch expressions to be exhaustive, so this check does not enforce default branches on such expressions.  ```bash /var/tmp $ javac Switch.java  /var/tmp $ cat config.xml                                /var/tmp $ cat Switch.java public class Switch {     public enum Options {         ONE,         TWO,         THREE     }      public void foo1(Options option) {         int num = switch (option) { // ok             case ONE:                 yield 1;             case TWO:                 yield 2;             case THREE:                 yield 3;         };     }      public void foo2(Options option) {         assert Integer.valueOf(1).equals(switch (option) { // ok             case ONE -> 1;             case TWO -> 2;             case THREE -> 3;         });     }      public void bar1(Options option) {         int num;         num = switch (option) { // violation, but not expected              case ONE -> 1;             case TWO -> 2;             case THREE -> 3;         };     }      public void bar2(Options option) {         assert 1 < switch (option) { // violation, but not expected              case ONE -> 1;             case TWO -> 2;             case THREE -> 3;         };     } }  /var/tmp $ RUN_LOCALE="-Duser.language=en -Duser.country=US" /var/tmp $ java $RUN_LOCALE -jar checkstyle-9.0.1-all.jar -c config.xml Switch.java Starting audit... [ERROR] /var/tmp/Switch.java:29:15: switch without "default" clause. [MissingSwitchDefault] [ERROR] /var/tmp/Switch.java:37:20: switch without "default" clause. [MissingSwitchDefault] Audit done. Checkstyle ends with 2 errors. ```   Run script  ```bash cat > Switch.java  2;             case THREE -> 3;         });     }      public void bar1(Options option) {         int num;         num = switch (option) { // violation, but not expected              case ONE -> 1;             case TWO -> 2;             case THREE -> 3;         };     }      public void bar2(Options option) {         assert 1 < switch (option) { // violation, but not expected              case ONE -> 1;             case TWO -> 2;             case THREE -> 3;         };     } } EOF  javac Switch.java  cat > config.xml

column3: WhitespaceAround misrecognizes white spaces after emojis
column4: I have read check documentation: http://checkstyle.org/config_whitespace.html#WhitespaceAround - Checkstyle version: 9.0 - No custom configuration for `WhitespaceAround` - Error message    ```bash   QueryStringEncoderBenchmark.java:62:32: WhitespaceAround: '+' is not preceded with whitespace. [WhitespaceAround]   ``` - Code: https://github.com/line/armeria/blob/2caa0f8812e7435b7141136da95b5fd1f3efa2be/benchmarks/jmh/src/jmh/java/com/linecorp/armeria/common/QueryStringEncoderBenchmark.java#L62   ```java    for (int i = 0; i < 10; i++) {             unicode.add("알파" + i, "베타・감마") // Hangul                    .add("アルファ" + i, "ベータ・ガンマ")                     .add("电买车红" + i, "无东马风")                     .add("🎄❤️😂" + i, "🎅🔥😊🎁"); // This is line 62.   }   ```  ---  White spaces after emojis should be recognized by WhitespaceAround module.  ---

column3: Add Checkstyle from PR to Github's Diff Report
column4: I have noticed this for a while and couldn't find an issue so I am creating this now.  When Github runs regression on a project, it only runs it on checkstyle master( this is what defined in property file). While this ideal we run it on checkstyle, when fixing a bug, if the bug doesn't have files that reproduce problem in master we get a clean report showing no differences. See https://github.com/checkstyle/checkstyle/pull/10857 as the latest example.  This "clean" report requires extra precautions as the users currently supply the config. If the config is wrong in any way, this clean report can be a false positive and may be easy to miss.  Users are required to create tests and input files for their fixes to show the error the user reported is fixed and won't come back again. While we look at these, it is not always straightforward if the issue is recreated correctly. Slight deviations could fail to duplicate the issue and we are looking at the wrong thing.  If we ran regression on this PR version of checkstyle ( specific fork and branch name from PR), it should not be clean and come back with either an error removed (fixing a bug) or a new violation (fixing a false negative). So this run, would also give us the extra confidence that running the new PR on the future master would be a good result and less likely to cause an issue after merge. It would be just regular execution, but in config we will put property for fork name and branch name to get checkstyle sources from PR. So it will be update to support PRs fork name and branch name in file with list of projects .  We currently do something similar to this for wercker, but it only looks for no exceptions, not new/removed violations. https://github.com/checkstyle/checkstyle/blob/1acbabe78a6f9a3423b59cdb9b04dec74657b7be/.ci/wercker.sh#L239 https://github.com/checkstyle/contribution/blob/master/checkstyle-tester/projects-for-wercker.properties#L8

I have executed the cli and showed it below, as cli describes the problem better than 1,000 words  **How it should work:**  ```bash /var/tmp $ javac YOUR_FILE.java  /var/tmp $ cat config.xml                                   /var/tmp $ cat Test.java  public class Test {     void method() {         Object o = "q";         if (o instanceof String s) { // violation, unused pattern variable 's'         }     } }  /var/tmp $ RUN_LOCALE="-Duser.language=en -Duser.country=US" /var/tmp $ java $RUN_LOCALE -jar checkstyle-9.XX-all.jar -c config.xml Test.java Starting audit... [ERROR] /var/tmp/Test.java:4:33: Unused pattern variable 's'. [UnusedPatternVariable] Audit done. Checkstyle ends with 1 errors. ```  Resolving the scope of a pattern variable is not a simple task and requires the implementation of logic mentioned in https://github.com/checkstyle/checkstyle/issues/7504#issuecomment-974776332. Hence a new check would be the best option IMO.  Edit- Resolving the scope of pattern variables would be helpful to solve other issues, for eg - #10969

column3: Support patterns in switch (preview-feature in Java 17) as described by JEP 406
column4: I have downloaded the latest cli from: https://checkstyle.org/cmdline.html#Download_and_Run I have executed the cli and showed it below, as cli describes the problem better than 1,000 words  **How it works Now:**  ```bash $ java -version openjdk version "17" 2021-09-14 OpenJDK Runtime Environment 21.9 (build 17+35) OpenJDK 64-Bit Server VM 21.9 (build 17+35, mixed mode, sharing)  $ javac --version javac 17  $ javac --release 17 --enable-preview Main.java Note: Main.java uses preview features of Java SE 17. Note: Recompile with -Xlint:preview for details.  $ cat config.xml                        $ cat Main.java package com.github.sviperll.checkstylejep406;  public class Main {     public static void main(String[] args) {         Object value = Integer.valueOf(42);         String result = switch (value) {             case null -> "It's null...";             case String s -> "It's a string: " + s;             case Integer i -> "It's an integer: " + i.toString();             case Object v -> "It's something else: " + v.toString();         };         System.out.println(result);     } }  $ RUN_LOCALE="-Duser.language=en -Duser.country=US" $ java $RUN_LOCALE -jar checkstyle-9.0.1-all.jar -c config.xml Main.java Starting audit... com.puppycrawl.tools.checkstyle.api.CheckstyleException: Exception was thrown while processing Main.java 	at com.puppycrawl.tools.checkstyle.Checker.processFiles(Checker.java:302) 	at com.puppycrawl.tools.checkstyle.Checker.process(Checker.java:221) 	at com.puppycrawl.tools.checkstyle.Main.runCheckstyle(Main.java:409) 	at com.puppycrawl.tools.checkstyle.Main.runCli(Main.java:332) 	at com.puppycrawl.tools.checkstyle.Main.execute(Main.java:191) 	at com.puppycrawl.tools.checkstyle.Main.main(Main.java:126) Caused by: com.puppycrawl.tools.checkstyle.api.CheckstyleException: IllegalStateException occurred while parsing file /home/vir/code/checkstyle-jep406/Main.java. 	at com.puppycrawl.tools.checkstyle.JavaParser.parse(JavaParser.java:104) 	at com.puppycrawl.tools.checkstyle.TreeWalker.processFiltered(TreeWalker.java:152) 	at com.puppycrawl.tools.checkstyle.api.AbstractFileSetCheck.process(AbstractFileSetCheck.java:87) 	at com.puppycrawl.tools.checkstyle.Checker.processFile(Checker.java:328) 	at com.puppycrawl.tools.checkstyle.Checker.processFiles(Checker.java:289) 	... 5 more Caused by: java.lang.IllegalStateException: 5:38: mismatched input '(' expecting ';' 	at com.puppycrawl.tools.checkstyle.JavaParser$CheckstyleErrorListener.syntaxError(JavaParser.java:251) 	at org.antlr.v4.runtime.ProxyErrorListener.syntaxError(ProxyErrorListener.java:41) 	at org.antlr.v4.runtime.Parser.notifyErrorListeners(Parser.java:544) 	at by: org.antlr.v4.runtime.InputMismatchException 	... 23 more Checkstyle ends with 1 errors.  ```  **Is your feature request related to a problem? Please describe.** The problem is that checkstyle crashes when there is a switch that uses pattern-matching  **Describe the solution you'd like**  Checkstyle should update Java-language grammer definition according to the grammar changes described in [JEP 406](https://openjdk.java.net/jeps/406)  Relevant Java Language changes are [drafted by Gavin Bierman](http://cr.openjdk.java.net/~gbierman/jep406/jep406-20210608/specs/patterns-switch-jls.html#jls-14.11.1) to be amended to Java Language Specification in the future.  Here are some excerpts from the JEP:  > We enhance switch statements and expressions in two ways: > >  1. Extend case labels to include patterns in addition to constants, and >  2. Introduce two new kinds of patterns: guarded patterns and parenthesized patterns. >  ...  > First, we introduce a new `null` label for a case, which clearly matches when the value of the selector expression is `null`.  ...  > Consequently, the previous example suggests that we should support a `case null, String s ->` label.  ...  > (The reverse form, case String s, null should also be allowed and behave identically.)  ...  > To do so we introduce a new default case label: > `case null, default ->`  ...  > More precisely, we change the grammar of patterns. > Assuming that the record patterns and array patterns of JEP 405 are added, the grammar for patterns will become: > > ```` >     Pattern: >       PrimaryPattern >       GuardedPattern > >     GuardedPattern: >       PrimaryPattern && ConditionalAndExpression > >     PrimaryPattern: >       TypePattern >       ( Pattern )

column3: Indent error message uses wrong token type
column4: I have checked docs: https://checkstyle.org/config_misc.html#Indentation I have downloaded the latest checkstyle from: https://checkstyle.org/cmdline.html#Download_and_Run I have executed the cli and showed it below, as cli describes the problem better than 1,000 words  ```bash /var/tmp $ javac Main.java # Main.class created  /var/tmp $ cat config.xml                                                                                               /var/tmp $ cat Main.java public class Main {     void test() {         switch (1) {         default: test();         }     } }  /var/tmp $ RUN_LOCALE="-Duser.language=en -Duser.country=US" /var/tmp $ java $RUN_LOCALE -jar checkstyle-8.44-all.jar -c config.xml Main.java Starting audit... [ERROR] .../Main.java:4:9: 'case' child has incorrect indentation level 8, expected level should be 12. [Indentation] Audit done. Checkstyle ends with 1 errors. ```  I am expecting error message to use corrent token type "default" instead of "case", like: `Main.java:4:9: 'default' child has incorrect indentation level 8, expected level should be 12. [Indentation]`

column3: SINGLE_LINE_COMMENT breaks FullIdent.createFullIdent().getText() when isCommentNodesRequired is true
column4: i encountered an issue when i use FullIdent.createFullIdent().getText() when turn on the processing of comment nodes i my custom check that extends `AbstractCheck`  ```java     @Override     public boolean isCommentNodesRequired() {         return true;     } ```  my sample class is:  ```java package de.test;  @Import(packages = { //         ClassA.class // }) public class Input { } ``` I'm interested in the node that contains the `ClassA.class` in the array initializer  so the code to get that part is while the argument is the EXPR ```java     public static String getExprStringRepresentation(final DetailAST expression) {         final DetailAST value = expression.getFirstChild();         String stringRepresentation = null;          if (value.getType() == TokenTypes.DOT) {             stringRepresentation = FullIdent.createFullIdent(value).getText();         } else if (LITERALS.contains(value.getType())) {             stringRepresentation = value.getText();         }         return stringRepresentation;     } ```   when I turn off comment nodes processing I'm getting the following tree ``` |   |   |       |--EXPR -> EXPR [4:14] |   |   |       |   `--DOT -> . [4:14] |   |   |       |       |--IDENT -> ClassA [4:8] |   |   |       |       `--LITERAL_CLASS -> class [4:15] |   |   |       `--RCURLY -> } [5:0] ``` resulting in `ClassA.class` as the value of `stringRepresentation`  when I turn it on ``` |   |   |       |--EXPR -> EXPR [4:14] |   |   |       |   `--DOT -> . [4:14] |   |   |       |       |--SINGLE_LINE_COMMENT -> // [3:21] |   |   |       |       |   `--COMMENT_CONTENT -> \n [3:23] |   |   |       |       |--IDENT -> ClassA [4:8] |   |   |       |       `--LITERAL_CLASS -> class [4:15] |   |   |       |--SINGLE_LINE_COMMENT -> // [4:21] |   |   |       |   `--COMMENT_CONTENT -> \n [4:23] |   |   |       `--RCURLY -> } [5:0] ``` it results in `//.ClassA`  and here the `.class` part is missing.   I think the `SINGLE_LINE_COMMENT` should be placed before the `DOT` instead of inside which obviously breaks the `getText` method, as this one only consider the first two child of the `DOT`

I consider checkstyle used in a maven multi-module project.  		 		3.1.2 		 		9.1  I end with OutOfMemory issues in a compilation step going through all modules:  16:03:39,815 [INFO] --- maven-compiler-plugin:3.8.1:compile (default-compile) @ dp-proxy --- 16:03:39,819 [INFO] Changes detected - recompiling the module! 16:03:39,976 [INFO] Compiling 26 source files to /home/circleci/project/exec/dp-proxy/target/classes java.lang.OutOfMemoryError: Java heap space Dumping heap to java_pid153.hprof ... Heap dump file created [912601987 bytes in 4.290 secs]  I can not share the code as the project is private.      I feel the issue is some of these ANTLR objects are not cleaned from one module to another.  I can dig deeper in the HeapDump through MAT if helpful.

https://github.com/checkstyle/checkstyle/runs/4453342391?check_suite_focus=true#step:9:36  ``` Error: git repository ../../checkstyle does not have a branch with name 'origin/"issue-11001"'! Error: origin/"issue-11001" is not an exiting git branch! Caught: java.lang.IllegalArgumentException: Error: invalid command line arguments! ``` The `diff_report.yml` workflow was failing because the `REF` environment variable was getting set in the form `origin/"branchname"` (extra doublequotes around the branch name)  The extra quotes were coming from the jq command, which outputs strings in json format (that is, doublequoted). This PR uses jq's --raw-output option:  >With this option, if the filter's result is a string then it will be written directly to standard output rather than being formatted as a JSON string with quotes. This can be useful for making jq filters talk to non-JSON-based systems.  It also removes `xargs` from the commit_sha pipeline, as it's no longer needed.

column3: Change type "Regular Expression" to "Pattern" in docs
column4: https://checkstyle.org/property_types.html#Pattern > This type represents a regular expression. The string representation is parsed using java.util.regex package.   https://checkstyle.org/property_types.html#RegularExpression > This type represents a regular expression. The string representation is parsed using java.util.regex package.   I have seen `regexp` since the beginning in the history. Pattern came about in a064a46d47ac0f0c57163d455f3bc6d16f19f6c4 which was very recently. Commit message misleads on it being added on purpose but this probably all leads back to #8328 and https://github.com/checkstyle/checkstyle/issues/8328#issuecomment-651952351 .  Since there was some discussion on this, I am hesitant to say we can change it.  _Originally posted by @rnveach in https://github.com/checkstyle/checkstyle/pull/10826#discussion_r718087111_

column3: LocalVariableName: false negative on pattern variable
column4: https://checkstyle.org/config_naming.html#LocalVariableName  ```` $ cat TestClass.java public class Test {     public void run(String... arguments) {         final Object o = 45;         if (o instanceof String BAD) {             System.out.println(BAD);         }     } }  $ cat TestConfig.xml                         $ java -jar checkstyle-9.0.1-all.jar -c TestConfig.xml TestClass.java Starting audit... Audit done. ````  I am expecting a violation on line 5 since BAD is a local variable and it doesn't start with a lower case as is default required.

column3: LocalFinalVariableName: false negative on pattern variable
column4: https://checkstyle.org/config_naming.html#LocalFinalVariableName  ```` $ cat TestClass.java public class Test {     public void run(String... arguments) {         final Object o = 45;         if (o instanceof final String BAD) {             System.out.println(BAD);         }     } }  $ cat TestConfig.xml                         $ java -jar checkstyle-9.0.1-all.jar -c TestConfig.xml TestClass.java Starting audit... Audit done. ````  I am expecting a violation on line 5 since `BAD` is a local, final variable and it doesn't start with a lower case as is default required.  ``` public class Test {     public void run(String... arguments) {         final Object o = 45;         if (o instanceof final String BAD) {             o = 34;  // javac: Test.java:5: error: cannot assign a value to final variable o             System.out.println(BAD);         }     } } ```

column3: SuppressWarnings: support not working on local variables
column4: https://checkstyle.org/config_filters.html#SuppressWarningsFilter_Description  ```` $ cat TestClass.java public class TestClass {     @SuppressWarnings("MagicNumber")     private int A = 8;      @SuppressWarnings("MagicNumber")     void method() {         int b = 8;     }      void method2() {         @SuppressWarnings("MagicNumber")         int c = 8;     } }  $ cat TestConfig.xml                            $ java -jar checkstyle-8.42-all.jar -c TestConfig.xml TestClass.java Starting audit... [ERROR] TestClass.java:12:17: '8' is a magic number. [MagicNumber] Audit done. Checkstyle ends with 1 errors. ````  Suppression on line 3 on field works. Ok. Suppression on line 7 on method works. Ok. Suppression on line 12 does not work even though the annotation is added. This is the point of this issue.  I don't see why annotations on variables should not be supported as long as the code compiles, which it does.  Since suppression location is valid to me, it seems we should support this and be able to suppress violations in this manner as this is what check is meant to do.

https://app.travis-ci.com/github/checkstyle/checkstyle/jobs/537716352#L643  ``` * What went wrong:  Error resolving plugin [id: 'com.github.autostyle', version: '3.1']  > Could not resolve all dependencies for configuration 'detachedConfiguration2'.     > Could not determine artifacts for com.github.autostyle:com.github.autostyle.gradle.plugin:3.1        > Could not get resource 'https://plugins.gradle.org/m2/com/github/autostyle/com.github.autostyle.gradle.plugin/3.1/com.github.autostyle.gradle.plugin-3.1.jar'.           > Could not HEAD 'https://jcenter.bintray.com/com/github/autostyle/com.github.autostyle.gradle.plugin/3.1/com.github.autostyle.gradle.plugin-3.1.jar'.              > Read timed out   ```

column3: Extend RedundantModifierCheck with STRICTFP token for java 17
column4: http://checkstyle.sourceforge.net/config_modifier.html#RedundantModifier Reason: since java 17 there is no need for this modifier, see details in [JEP 306](https://openjdk.java.net/jeps/306)  Suggestion is to add this token to list of acceptable tokens, but not default to make sure it will not break existing builds.  ```bash /var/tmp $ cat config.xml                                                     /var/tmp $ cat Test.java class Test {   void strictfp method(){} // violation } ``` Expected - violation reported on line with violation comment

Hi,  I'm using CheckStyle with Gradle and I'm using `SuppressionsFilter`.  - without `SuppressionsFilter` and `./gradlew build` => pass - without `SuppressionsFilter` and `./gradlew build -Dcheckstyle.enableExternalDtdLoad=true` => pass - with `SuppressionsFilter` and `./gradlew build` => fail - with `SuppressionsFilter` and `./gradlew build -Dcheckstyle.enableExternalDtdLoad=true` => pass  So this error is related to https://github.com/checkstyle/checkstyle/issues/6474.  The Gradle plugin seems to use the Ant task (see logs below) and it looks like the Ant task is not getting the DTD from the CheckStyle JAR but from the internet only. column3: Activating a research fault localization bot on your project?
column4: Hi!   We are software engineering researchers and are currently looking for active open-source projects where we could test a new cool software bot: flacocobot!  When a new pull request is open, if it has test failures/errors, flacocobot analyzes the failure and posts a diagnosis as comments to the pull request, highlighting the most suspicious lines that likely need to be analyzed to fix the bug.  flacocobot works as follows:  - When a new PR is open, if the test suite fails, flacocobot starts its analysis. - The top k suspicious (potentially buggy) lines of code are then highlighted as comments to the PR.  We would love to have your feedback in order to understand what you like or you do not like, what we can improve, and if you find it useful!  If you are interested in trying it, we will run flacocobot on your project for a period of two weeks and then give you a 1-minute questionnaire to collect your feedback.  What do you think? Can we activate flacocobot for [checkstyle](https://github.com/checkstyle/checkstyle)?  Thanks,  Davide (@dginelli), André (@andre15silva), Matias (@martinezmatias), Benjamin (@danglotb), Martin (@monperrus)  You can find out more in our tools repos: - https://github.com/SpoonLabs/flacoco - https://github.com/eclipse/repairnator

column3: Can we skip via checkstyle via command line or build.gradle
column4: Hi Team, sonarqube: 8.9 plugin: checkstyle: 4.29 We have project with huge code can we skip chekcstyle via command line or build.gradle If yes how we can skip.  Below these are not helped checkstyleMain {     ignoreFailures = true }  checkstyle {    ignoreFailures = true }  checkstyleTask.ignoreFailures = true  Please help on this part.  I have read check documentation: https://checkstyle.org/config_xxxxxx.html#NameOfAffectedCheck I have downloaded the latest checkstyle from: https://checkstyle.org/cmdline.html#Download_and_Run I have executed the cli and showed it below, as cli describes the problem better than 1,000 words  ```bash /var/tmp $ javac YOUR_FILE.java #[[MAKE SURE THERE IS SUCCESSFUL COMPILATION]]  /var/tmp $ cat config.xml #[[PLACE YOUR OUTPUT HERE]]  /var/tmp $ cat YOUR_FILE.java #[[PLACE YOU OUTPUT HERE]]  /var/tmp $ RUN_LOCALE="-Duser.language=en -Duser.country=US" /var/tmp $ java $RUN_LOCALE -jar checkstyle-X.XX-all.jar -c config.xml YOUR_FILE.java #[[PLACE YOUR OUTPUT HERE]] ```  For Windows users, please use `type` instead of `cat` and run  ```cmd set RUN_LOCALE="-Duser.language=en -Duser.country=US" java %RUN_LOCALE% -jar checkstyle-X.XX-all.jar -c config.xml YOUR_FILE.java ```  in place of the last 2 commands above.  ---  **Describe what you expect in detail.**  ---  Still not clear ??? see example - https://checkstyle.org/report_issue.html#How_to_report_a_bug.3F  ATTENTION: FAILURE TO FOLLOW THE ABOVE TEMPLATE WILL RESULT IN THE ISSUE BEING CLOSED.

Since the build is configured to run on `1.8`, I had to modify the source+target language to allow for the reproducer test-case, which I've prepared here: this:   ``` java.lang.NullPointerException: Cannot invoke "com.puppycrawl.tools.checkstyle.api.DetailAST.getFirstChild()" because "modifiers" is null 	at com.puppycrawl.tools.checkstyle.checks.coding.IllegalTypeCheck.isContainVerifiableType(IllegalTypeCheck.java:516) 	at com.puppycrawl.tools.checkstyle.checks.coding.IllegalTypeCheck.isVerifiable(IllegalTypeCheck.java:502) 	at com.puppycrawl.tools.checkstyle.Checker.processFile(Checker.java:328) 	at com.puppycrawl.tools.checkstyle.Checker.processFiles(Checker.java:289) ```  My configuration of the check is baked into the comment in the tested source file.  If I change  ``` memberModifiers = LITERAL_PUBLIC, LITERAL_PROTECTED, LITERAL_STATIC ```  to   ``` memberModifiers = (default) ```  it starts to pass  ...  Am I configuring it incorrectly? IMHO it should not throw an NPE even when configured incorrectly.

column3: Add check that disallows blank lines between annotations
column4: Given a class like the following:  ``` @interface Foo {      String value() default "";  }  @interface Bar {}  public class InputAdjacentAnnotationCheck {      @Foo // ok     @Bar // violation     /** my javadoc */     String field1;      @Foo // ok     @Bar // violation      /** my javadoc */     String field2;      @Foo // violation      @Bar // violation      void m1() {}      @Foo( value =                   "1234" ) // ok     @Bar // ok     void m2() {}      void m3( @Foo String bar, // ok              @Bar             // ok                      String foo,              @Foo             //violation                       String abc ) {} } ```  Checkstyle should have rule that checks for adjacent annotations. The expected errors for the above class can be something like  ``` 12:5: Annotation 'Bar' should be adjacent to its sibling at line '14'. 17:5: Annotation 'Bar' should be adjacent to its sibling at line '20'. 22:5: Annotation 'Foo' should be adjacent to its sibling at line '24'. 24:5: Annotation 'Bar' should be adjacent to its sibling at line '26'. 36:14: Annotation 'Foo' should be adjacent to its sibling at line '38' ```  The error messages obviously highlight where the 'lonely' annotation is, along with the line number of its sibling.   Configuration-wise, it's the same as the `AnnotationOnSameLineCheck`, so you can configure which tokens to check against.  ```                              ```  Draft PR with implementation https://github.com/checkstyle/checkstyle/pull/10789/files that can be reused to continue

column4:
From: https://github.com/checkstyle/checkstyle/pull/10368#discussion_r671740246  ``` $ cat Test.java  class Test{     public void foo() {            int num1; //Violation Comment              int num2; // OK              bool isTrue; //Incorrect Comment              /*Incorrect Block Comment */       int num3;              /* Correct Block Comment */       int num4;              /**        *Incorrect Block Comment.        */       int num5;              /*        *Incorrect Block Comment.        */       int num6;                    /* Correct Block Comment        */       int num7;              /*        * Correct Block Comment        */       int num8;              /*Incorrect Block Comment.        * Correct Block Comment.        */       int num9;              /* Correct Block Comment.        *Incorrect Block Comment.        */       int num10;     } }  $ cat config.xml                                                                                $ java -jar checkstyle-8.45-SNAPSHOT-all.jar -c config.xml Test.java Starting audit... [ERROR] /home/akmo/GitHub/Test/MatchXpath/Test.java:4:17: Single line comment text should start with space. [singleLineCommentStartWithSpace] [ERROR] /home/akmo/GitHub/Test/MatchXpath/Test.java:8:20: Single line comment text should start with space. [singleLineCommentStartWithSpace] [ERROR] /home/akmo/GitHub/Test/MatchXpath/Test.java:10:7: Block comment text should start with space after asterisk. [blockCommentStartWithSpace] [ERROR] /home/akmo/GitHub/Test/MatchXpath/Test.java:16:7: Block comment text should start with space after asterisk. [blockCommentStartWithSpace] [ERROR] /home/akmo/GitHub/Test/MatchXpath/Test.java:21:7: Block comment text should start with space after asterisk. [blockCommentStartWithSpace] [ERROR] /home/akmo/GitHub/Test/MatchXpath/Test.java:35:7: Block comment text should start with space after asterisk. [blockCommentStartWithSpace] [ERROR] /home/akmo/GitHub/Test/MatchXpath/Test.java:40:7: Block comment text should start with space after asterisk. [blockCommentStartWithSpace] Audit done. Checkstyle ends with 7 errors. ```  Cases: 1. `not(@text = '
')` - For cases like just `//` where `not(starts-with(@text, ' ')` is true. Found in almost all files. Eg: [Empty comment](https://github.com/checkstyle/checkstyle/blob/b557d011379afb9a647127fec95e20ae8d437f0d/src/test/java/com/puppycrawl/tools/checkstyle/MainTest.java#L4)  2. `not(ends-with(@text, '//
'))` - For cases like `////////////////////////////
` where `not(starts-with(@text, ' ')` is true. Found in almost all files. Eg: [Comment](https://github.com/checkstyle/checkstyle/blob/b557d011379afb9a647127fec95e20ae8d437f0d/src/test/java/com/puppycrawl/tools/checkstyle/MainTest.java#L18)

From https://github.com/checkstyle/sonar-checkstyle/pull/366#issuecomment-823258678:  > the error received does not (seem to) relate to the plugin, as far as i figured out.  > research shows that jdk bundled the xml reader stuff at some point but some plugins still seem to use xerces. depending on the implementation used for DocumentBuilderFactory it can be that xerces results in such errors. i am more puzzled by the fact that this error never occurred before.  > either way, dependency tree analysis shows excluding xerces coming in from direct dependencies of the plugin does not resolve it. there's a sonar java dependency on xerces; however, we have that exact version of sonar java since upgrading to 7.8 as the main sonar version and never had problems (neither with the previous release) i also do not find any release version not including the dependencies containing xerces; hence, i doubt this dependency is the cause...  Errors mentioned above, from https://travis-ci.org/github/checkstyle/sonar-checkstyle/jobs/772831715 :  ```bash  ➜  sonar-checkstyle git:(master) mvn -e clean install ... [ERROR] test(org.sonar.plugins.checkstyle.CheckstyleRulesDefinitionTest)  Time elapsed: 0.292 s

column3: Upgrade Java Grammar from ANTLR2 to ANTLR4
column4: From https://github.com/checkstyle/checkstyle/wiki/Checkstyle-GSoC-2021-Project-Ideas#project-name-upgrade-java-grammar-from-antlr2-to-antlr4:  > Checkstyle needs to have new Java grammar that is based on ANTLR4 version. This task is very difficult but it is critical for Checkstyle as ANTLR2 library is not supported (from 2006) and is far less efficient. Old version has a bunch of syntax analysis limitations that have already been resolved in ANTLR4. Our team is already experiencing difficulties with support of current grammar as it is too complicated due to limited parsing abilities of ANTLR2.  In this issue, we can discuss finer points of this upgrade and remaining issues from https://github.com/checkstyle-antlr4/checkstyle-antlr4:  [Grammar should use all caps in naming of literals ](https://github.com/checkstyle-antlr4/checkstyle-antlr4/issues/22)  [Criteria for main repo merge](https://github.com/checkstyle-antlr4/checkstyle-antlr4/issues/13)  [Add EOF token to AST](https://github.com/checkstyle-antlr4/checkstyle-antlr4/issues/12)

From https://github.com/checkstyle/checkstyle/pull/9942#discussion_r646189170 https://checkstyle.org/config_javadoc.html#AtclauseOrder The default tagOrder specified in documentation and actual default tagOrder differ.  Documentation- https://github.com/checkstyle/checkstyle/blob/5738af2e9aa34f5a7e66fe5bb412aa7b5d0345ab/src/main/java/com/puppycrawl/tools/checkstyle/checks/javadoc/AtclauseOrderCheck.java#L77-L78  Actual- https://github.com/checkstyle/checkstyle/blob/5738af2e9aa34f5a7e66fe5bb412aa7b5d0345ab/src/main/java/com/puppycrawl/tools/checkstyle/checks/javadoc/AtclauseOrderCheck.java#L161-L168  This change appeared in #6938 while sorting values alphabetically for String set properties.

org.codehaus.plexus.classworlds.launcher.Launcher.mainWithExitCode(Launcher.java:406) 	at org.codehaus.plexus.classworlds.launcher.Launcher.main(Launcher.java:347) Caused by: java.lang.StackOverflowError 	at net.sf.saxon.tree.iter.ArrayIterator$OfNodes.next(ArrayIterator.java:226) 	at net.sf.saxon.tree.util.Navigator$DescendantEnumeration.next(Navigator.java:1323) ... Caught: groovy.lang.GroovyRuntimeException: Error: ! groovy.lang.GroovyRuntimeException: Error: ! 	at java.base/jdk.internal.reflect.NativeConstructorAccessorImpl.newInstance0(Native Method) 	at java.base/jdk.internal.reflect.NativeConstructorAccessorImpl.newInstance(NativeConstructorAccessorImpl.java:62) 	at java.base/jdk.internal.reflect.DelegatingConstructorAccessorImpl.newInstance(DelegatingConstructorAccessorImpl.java:45) 	at diff.executeCmd(diff.groovy:672) 	at diff.executeCmd(diff.groovy:665) 	at diff$executeCmd$12.callCurrent(Unknown Source) 	at diff.runMavenExecution(diff.groovy:637) 	at java.base/jdk.internal.reflect.NativeMethodAccessorImpl.invoke0(Native Method) 	at java.base/jdk.internal.reflect.NativeMethodAccessorImpl.invoke(NativeMethodAccessorImpl.java:62) 	at java.base/jdk.internal.reflect.DelegatingMethodAccessorImpl.invoke(DelegatingMethodAccessorImpl.java:43) 	at diff$_generateCheckstyleReport_closure4.doCall(diff.groovy:291) 	at java.base/jdk.internal.reflect.NativeMethodAccessorImpl.invoke0(Native Method) 	at java.base/jdk.internal.reflect.NativeMethodAccessorImpl.invoke(NativeMethodAccessorImpl.java:62) 	at java.base/jdk.internal.reflect.DelegatingMethodAccessorImpl.invoke(DelegatingMethodAccessorImpl.java:43) 	at diff.generateCheckstyleReport(diff.groovy:264) 	at diff$generateCheckstyleReport$10.callCurrent(Unknown Source) 	at diff.launchCheckstyleReport(diff.groovy:224) 	at diff$launchCheckstyleReport$6.callCurrent(Unknown Source) 	at diff.run(diff.groovy:33) 	at java.base/jdk.internal.reflect.NativeMethodAccessorImpl.invoke0(Native Method) 	at java.base/jdk.internal.reflect.NativeMethodAccessorImpl.invoke(NativeMethodAccessorImpl.java:62) 	at java.base/jdk.internal.reflect.DelegatingMethodAccessorImpl.invoke(DelegatingMethodAccessorImpl.java:43) ``` I feel this is a duplicate of #9193 #9149 but still wanted to point this out. The issue was first found at https://github.com/checkstyle/checkstyle/pull/10825#issuecomment-934327047 but I reduced the size of the file as a workaround to the extent where I was getting stack overflow error from original logic but not from the changed one.

column3: infra: parallelize no-exception javadoc github workflow
column4: From https://github.com/checkstyle/checkstyle/pull/10143#pullrequestreview-690624945:  > it would be better to split such big job (21 min) to multiple each execution separately, it will make it more quick by parallelism and easy to restart only single execution.

column3: RedundantModifierCheck only reports first instance of redundant modifier
column4: From https://checkstyle.sourceforge.io/config_modifier.html#RedundantModifier :  > Enums by definition are static implicit subclasses of java.lang.Enum. So, the static modifier on the enums is redundant. In addition, if enum is inside of interface, public modifier is also redundant.  Noticed in https://github.com/checkstyle/checkstyle/pull/10804   ```bash ➜  company cat config.xml                                                                                                                          ➜  company cat Test.java  interface Test {     public enum MyInnerEnum1 {} // violation     static enum MyInnerEnum2 {} // violation     public static enum MyInnerEnum3 {} // should be 2 violations     static public enum MyInnerEnum4 {} // should be 2 violations }  ➜  company javac Test.java   ➜  company java -jar checkstyle-9.0-all.jar -c config.xml Test.java Starting audit... [ERROR] /home/nick/IdeaProjects/Tester/src/com/company/Test.java:2:5: Redundant 'public' modifier. [RedundantModifier] [ERROR] /home/nick/IdeaProjects/Tester/src/com/company/Test.java:3:5: Redundant 'static' modifier. [RedundantModifier] [ERROR] /home/nick/IdeaProjects/Tester/src/com/company/Test.java:4:5: Redundant 'public' modifier. [RedundantModifier] [ERROR] /home/nick/IdeaProjects/Tester/src/com/company/Test.java:5:5: Redundant 'static' modifier. [RedundantModifier] Audit done. Checkstyle ends with 4 errors.  ``` I would expect checkstyle to report all redundant modifiers, like this:  ```bash  ➜  company java -jar checkstyle-9.0-all.jar -c config.xml Test.java Starting audit... [ERROR] /home/nick/IdeaProjects/Tester/src/com/company/Test.java:2:5: Redundant 'public' modifier. [RedundantModifier] [ERROR] /home/nick/IdeaProjects/Tester/src/com/company/Test.java:3:5: Redundant 'static' modifier. [RedundantModifier] [ERROR] /home/nick/IdeaProjects/Tester/src/com/company/Test.java:4:5: Redundant 'public' modifier. [RedundantModifier] [ERROR] /home/nick/IdeaProjects/Tester/src/com/company/Test.java:4:12: Redundant 'static' modifier. [RedundantModifier] [ERROR] /home/nick/IdeaProjects/Tester/src/com/company/Test.java:5:5: Redundant 'static' modifier. [RedundantModifier] [ERROR] /home/nick/IdeaProjects/Tester/src/com/company/Test.java:5:12: Redundant 'public' modifier. [RedundantModifier Audit done. Checkstyle ends with 4 errors.  ```

column3: minor: rename CheckstyleJavaParser.g4 and JavaLexer.g4 to JavaLanguageParser.g4 and JavaLanguageLexer.g4
column4: From discussion in GSOC discord with @rnveach , we have decided that it is a good idea to make the naming of the parser and lexer grammar consistent, i.e. `Checkstyle...`.   The parser grammar was renamed from `JavaParser` to `CheckstyleJavaParser` to avoid fully qualifying an instance of the `JavaParser` generated ANTLR class when we create it in the existing `JavaParser` class. The `JavaLexer` lexer grammar and generated class should also follow this naming convention.    From chat: > If we use JavaParser , then we are using an instance of a class called JavaParser in a class called JavaParser, and I have to fully qualify the name. Also, it kept opening the wrong file when I use the keystroke/open file dialog in intellij.  https://github.com/checkstyle/checkstyle/blob/b154154b6f935086d8a3609c17534188c0d720ae/src/main/java/com/puppycrawl/tools/checkstyle/JavaParser.java#L82-L92  ![Untitled](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/812984/129726358-a133bb51-fb4c-4272-ab4f-27b8203b170e.png)  ![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/812984/129727044-53144d66-5f2f-4839-b37e-ba0dcf754b27.png)

column3: Unit tests that involve `StackOverflow` should use limited stack size
column4: From discussion at https://github.com/checkstyle/checkstyle/pull/10600:  > The stack size depends on the platform (Java on 32-bit platforms uses a smaller stack). Moreover, this may vary depending on the JVM vendor.  > Ideally, we need to be able to explicitly run a test with limited stack size. I tried to do something like this in #9163 with a helper method:  > https://github.com/pbludov/checkstyle/commit/f3f96b326ec2901cfc3366e95787340e8e27a05c#diff-ae096b8cfa78e1dac18326e43375cbc21cc3b646bc99a85e49e83e971e88d68eR259  _Originally posted by @pbludov in https://github.com/checkstyle/checkstyle/issues/10600#issuecomment-896843237_  Due to differences in CI environment (type of machine, version/ vendor of Java, etc.) sometimes, the input at https://github.com/checkstyle/checkstyle/blob/5485431038c796622df4372f316fdcc4d31363cf/src/test/resources/com/puppycrawl/tools/checkstyle/javaparser/InputJavaParserNoStackOverflowOnDeepStringConcat.java will fail to kill pitest mutation in `JavaAstVisitor#visitBinOp`. Example: https://github.com/checkstyle/checkstyle/pull/10437/checks?check_run_id=3297051073  We have created a temporary fix for this case at https://github.com/checkstyle/checkstyle/pull/10600, but it would be ideal to ensure consistent behavior for all such tests.

column3: Create README for Java grammar updates
column4: From discussion at https://github.com/checkstyle/checkstyle/pull/10280#discussion_r686171354 and elsewhere, with the new ANTLR4 grammar and visitor combination to build Checkstyle's AST, it may not be obvious to contributors how to update the grammar and create the AST. I propose that we write a guide, which will walk through the entire process form start to finish. Points of discussion here include:  1. Location of README file in repo (or wiki)? 2. Areas of visitor/grammar that may need additional explanation 3. Best practices to mention 4. ??

From discussion at https://github.com/checkstyle/checkstyle/pull/10280#discussion_r681690879:  > Constructor is supposed to be block of code to initialize object.  I do not think anyone will call this initialize method more than one time, so I do not see a reason for it. Other approach is to make static factory methods for object creation.   _Originally posted by @strkkk in https://github.com/checkstyle/checkstyle/pull/10280#discussion_r681766838_  We should discuss alternatives to replace `initialize`, such as a constructor or factory method. This change must be made after https://github.com/checkstyle/checkstyle/pull/10280#pullrequestreview-722068600

column3: Restrict usage of org.junit.jupiter.api.Assertions package in tests
column4: Followed by  https://github.com/checkstyle/checkstyle/issues/9142  To make changes incrementally and to be sure that no junit assertions are left, it is better to forbid package `org.junit.jupiter.api.Assertions` package in tests   Scope of this issue - add import control rule to restrict usage of `org.junit.jupiter.api.Assertions` package - suppress all existing import control violations  @romani please read and approve

column3: minor: correct the wrong format of AST
column4: Fixes Issue: #9393    This PR changes all "+-" to "`-" , as mentioned in the issue.    Here is the rendered javadoc file generated using `mvn javadoc:javadoc` :  ![Screenshot (25)](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/75962762/141647571-6c7aa591-546f-499d-9805-200dade3d846.png)    **TEST.java :**  ```java @MyAnnotation package blah; ````  **Command :**  ``` java -jar checkstyle-9.1-all.jar -t TEST.java COMPILATION_UNIT -> COMPILATION_UNIT [1:14] `--PACKAGE_DEF -> package [1:14]     |--ANNOTATIONS -> ANNOTATIONS [1:0]     |   `--ANNOTATION -> ANNOTATION [1:0]     |       |--AT -> @ [1:0]     |       `--IDENT -> MyAnnotation [1:1]     |--IDENT -> blah [1:22]     `--SEMI -> ; [1:26] ```  **Code changes :**  ```java      *       * `--PACKAGE_DEF -> package      *     |--ANNOTATIONS -> ANNOTATIONS      *     |   `--ANNOTATION -> ANNOTATION      *     |       |--AT -> @      *     |       `--IDENT -> MyAnnotation      *     |--IDENT -> blah      *     `--SEMI -> ;      *  ```

column3: Issue #10749: Add support to take list of moduleFolders as input
column4: Fixes issue #10749: Currently moduleFolders names are hardcoded `checks`, `filters`, `filefilters`. It is not necessary for all folders to exist, if all three folders doesn't exist, util will stop. Instead the folders can be taken as inputs.

column4: Fixes #9455: update example of AST for TokenTypes.INSTANCE_INIT  ![Screenshot (607)](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/80591258/144652597-3fc874ae-3c4e-46fd-8a7a-98c2f615355f.png)  Test.java file: ``` public class MyClass {     private int foo;     {foo = 10;} } ```  AST printed through CLI: ``` COMPILATION_UNIT -> COMPILATION_UNIT [1:0] `--CLASS_DEF -> CLASS_DEF [1:0]     |--MODIFIERS -> MODIFIERS [1:0]     |   `--LITERAL_PUBLIC -> public [1:0]     |--LITERAL_CLASS -> class [1:7]     |--IDENT -> MyClass [1:13]     `--OBJBLOCK -> OBJBLOCK [1:21]         |--LCURLY -> { [1:21]         |--VARIABLE_DEF -> VARIABLE_DEF [2:4]         |   |--MODIFIERS -> MODIFIERS [2:4]         |   |   `--LITERAL_PRIVATE -> private [2:4]         |   |--TYPE -> TYPE [2:12]         |   |   `--LITERAL_INT -> int [2:12]         |   |--IDENT -> foo [2:16]         |   `--SEMI -> ; [2:19]         |--INSTANCE_INIT -> INSTANCE_INIT [3:4]         |   `--SLIST -> { [3:4]         |       |--EXPR -> EXPR [3:9]         |       |   `--ASSIGN -> = [3:9]         |       |       |--IDENT -> foo [3:5]         |       |       `--NUM_INT -> 10 [3:11]         |       |--SEMI -> ; [3:13]         |       `--RCURLY -> } [3:14]         `--RCURLY -> } [4:0] ```  The expected update for Javadoc is: ```  CLASS_DEF -> CLASS_DEF   |--MODIFIERS -> MODIFIERS   |   `--LITERAL_PUBLIC -> public   |--LITERAL_CLASS -> class   |--IDENT -> MyClass   `--OBJBLOCK -> OBJBLOCK       |--LCURLY -> {       |--VARIABLE_DEF -> VARIABLE_DEF       |   |--MODIFIERS -> MODIFIERS       |   |   `--LITERAL_PRIVATE -> private       |   |--TYPE -> TYPE       |   |   `--LITERAL_INT -> int       |   |--IDENT -> foo       |   `--SEMI -> ;       |--INSTANCE_INIT -> INSTANCE_INIT       |   `--SLIST -> {       |       |--EXPR -> EXPR       |       |   `--ASSIGN -> =       |       |       |--IDENT -> foo       |       |       `--NUM_INT -> 10       |       |--SEMI -> ;       |       `--RCURLY -> }       `--RCURLY -> } ```

column3: Issue #9372: Added example of AST for TokenTypes.ANNOTATION_MEMBER_VA…
