column3: Remove suppressions for original verify method or explain in comment
column4: Before: #10391 #10081  Scope of this issue: - Update test classes one by one (one PR for each test) - Migrate to new verify method - Make sure code coverage and pitest coverage didn't change - Remove suppressions for original `verify` method or expalin each/group of suppression why they stay permanent. All tests on fake/test Checks should be suppressed permanently, as there is no business value in such tests and they exists only for coverage of edge cases that are not achievable by existing public Checks.   Suppression: https://github.com/checkstyle/checkstyle/blob/0544f86f24ca3883393bd8c2f57105d77f2da3de/pom.xml#L1530 we need clear explanation on why each suppresion is required. If we are on lack of time to migrate, but there is no good reason to stay in permanent, separate issue should be create and placed as comment ``

column3: infra: activate CI item as issue #10778 is fixed
Azure container ubuntu version should be updated to  ubuntu-latest
column4: Azure container ubuntu version should be updated to  `ubuntu-latest`  `[warning]Ubuntu 16.04 LTS environment is deprecated and will be removed on September 20, 2021. Migrate to ubuntu-latest instead. For more details, see https://github.com/actions/virtual-environments/issues/3287.`  https://dev.azure.com/romanivanovjr/romanivanovjr/_build/results?buildId=3873&view=results

column3: minor: increase code coverage for meta data packages
Add links to projects with additional checkstyle checks to site
column4: At the moment there are links to related tools (plugins and other integrations) but it can be useful for user to find additional sources of checkstyle check, e.g. sevntu or https://checkstyle-addons.thomasjensen.com/#:~:text=Checkstyle%20Addons%20provides%20additional%20detectors,is%20well%20tested%20and%20stable.  There can be other custom useful checkstyle checks.  Idea came from feedback of one of the users.

column3: infra: specify heap size for diff report generation
column4: As we do for other `diff.groovy` usages such as `no-exception-test` CI tasks, we should specify a larger heap size for checkstyle execution while generating check behavior regression reports.  Examples: https://github.com/checkstyle/checkstyle/blob/003704a000881455349bd42bf9b16b91f2724ab9/.ci/no-exception-test.sh#L86 https://github.com/checkstyle/checkstyle/blob/003704a000881455349bd42bf9b16b91f2724ab9/.ci/no-exception-test.sh#L106 https://github.com/checkstyle/checkstyle/blob/003704a000881455349bd42bf9b16b91f2724ab9/.ci/no-exception-test.sh#L127 https://github.com/checkstyle/checkstyle/blob/003704a000881455349bd42bf9b16b91f2724ab9/.ci/no-exception-test.sh#L148  This should allow us to use openjdk16 project in https://github.com/checkstyle/contribution/blob/master/checkstyle-tester/projects-to-test-on-for-github-action.properties after https://github.com/checkstyle/checkstyle/issues/10934, as evidenced by successful `openjdk16-with-checks-nonjavadoc-error` execution at https://github.com/checkstyle/checkstyle/runs/4422293694?check_suite_focus=true with same heap size.  Right now, report generation is failing with OOM error on openjdk16: https://github.com/checkstyle/checkstyle/actions/runs/1541241529  Once this is merged, I will re-run report at https://github.com/checkstyle/checkstyle/pull/10999#issue-1070774832 to show successful report generation.

column3: Run regression testing in CI over openjdk16
column4: As proof of parsing capability last summer, we added `openjdk14-with-checks-nonjavadoc-error` to CI to make sure that we maintain the ability to parse openjdk14:  https://github.com/checkstyle/checkstyle/blob/5e510f7f1e2f5a19223b543c401a9486e0745bb8/.ci/no-exception-test.sh#L54-L73    Now that Checkstyle supports jdk16, we should update this job to parse https://github.com/AdoptOpenJDK/openjdk-jdk16.git, using the same method that `openjdk14-with-checks-nonjavadoc-error` uses, namely the `checks-nonjavadoc-error.xml` config and `BeforeExecutionExclusionFileFilter` modules for non-compilable files.

column3: Checkstyle fails to parse local enum and interface declarations
column4: As part of [JEP 395](https://openjdk.java.net/jeps/395), along with local records, we are able to declare local enums and interfaces. Checkstyle fails to parse the following:  ```bash ➜  src /usr/lib/jvm/java-16-openjdk/bin/javac Test.java  ➜  src cat Test.java  class Test {     void m() {         enum E {a, b, c};     } }  ➜  src java -jar checkstyle-8.44-all.jar -t Test.java com.puppycrawl.tools.checkstyle.api.CheckstyleException: IllegalStateException occurred while parsing file /home/nick/Desktop/Tester/src/Test.java.         at com.puppycrawl.tools.checkstyle.JavaParser.parse(JavaParser.java:120)         at com.puppycrawl.tools.checkstyle.JavaParser.parseFileText(JavaParser.java:137)         at com.puppycrawl.tools.checkstyle.JavaParser.parseFile(JavaParser.java:157)         at com.puppycrawl.tools.checkstyle.AstTreeStringPrinter.printFileAst(AstTreeStringPrinter.java:65)         at com.puppycrawl.tools.checkstyle.Main.runCli(Main.java:285)         at com.puppycrawl.tools.checkstyle.Main.execute(Main.java:191)         at com.puppycrawl.tools.checkstyle.Main.main(Main.java:126) Caused by: java.lang.IllegalStateException: /home/nick/Desktop/Tester/src/Test.java:3:9: expecting RCURLY, found 'enum' ...  ```  and    ```bash ➜  src /usr/lib/jvm/java-16-openjdk/bin/javac Test.java  ➜  src cat Test.java class Test {     void m() {         interface I{}     } }  ➜  src java -jar checkstyle-8.44-all.jar -t Test.java com.puppycrawl.tools.checkstyle.api.CheckstyleException: IllegalStateException occurred while parsing file /home/nick/Desktop/Tester/src/Test.java.         at com.puppycrawl.tools.checkstyle.JavaParser.parse(JavaParser.java:120)         at com.puppycrawl.tools.checkstyle.JavaParser.parseFileText(JavaParser.java:137)         at com.puppycrawl.tools.checkstyle.JavaParser.parseFile(JavaParser.java:157)         at com.puppycrawl.tools.checkstyle.AstTreeStringPrinter.printFileAst(AstTreeStringPrinter.java:65)         at com.puppycrawl.tools.checkstyle.Main.runCli(Main.java:285)         at com.puppycrawl.tools.checkstyle.Main.execute(Main.java:191)         at com.puppycrawl.tools.checkstyle.Main.main(Main.java:126) Caused by: java.lang.IllegalStateException: /home/nick/Desktop/Tester/src/Test.java:3:9: expecting RCURLY, found 'interface' ...  ```  I would expect Checkstyle to parse this code.

column3: All checks that use `AbstractCheck#getLine()` should check code points instead of characters for spacing
column4: Affected checks: https://checkstyle.sourceforge.io/config_misc.html#CommentsIndentation https://checkstyle.sourceforge.io/config_blocks.html#RightCurly https://checkstyle.sourceforge.io/config_blocks.html#LeftCurly https://checkstyle.sourceforge.io/config_whitespace.html#GenericWhitespace https://checkstyle.sourceforge.io/config_whitespace.html#NoWhitespaceBefore https://checkstyle.sourceforge.io/config_whitespace.html#SingleSpaceSeparator https://checkstyle.sourceforge.io/config_whitespace.html#NoWhitespaceAfter  ```bash  ➜  checks git:(issue-10920) grep -R 'getLine(' | grep -v "indentCheck\|\.getLine(\|int" indentation/CommentsIndentationCheck.java:        final String targetSourceLine = getLine(singleLineComment.getLineNo() - 1); indentation/CommentsIndentationCheck.java:        final String commentLine = getLine(blockComment.getLineNo() - 1); blocks/RightCurlyCheck.java:        else if (shouldBeAloneOnLine(option, details, getLine(details.rcurly.getLineNo() - 1))) { blocks/LeftCurlyCheck.java:        final String braceLine = getLine(brace.getLineNo() - 1); whitespace/WhitespaceAfterCheck.java:            final String line = getLine(targetAST.getLineNo() - 1); whitespace/WhitespaceAfterCheck.java:            final String line = getLine(ast.getLineNo() - 1); whitespace/GenericWhitespaceCheck.java:        final String line = getLine(ast.getLineNo() - 1); whitespace/GenericWhitespaceCheck.java:        final String line = getLine(ast.getLineNo() - 1); whitespace/NoWhitespaceBeforeCheck.java:        final String line = getLine(ast.getLineNo() - 1); whitespace/WhitespaceAroundCheck.java:            final String line = getLine(ast.getLineNo() - 1); whitespace/SingleSpaceSeparatorCheck.java:                            getLine(currentNode.getLineNo() - 1), whitespace/NoWhitespaceAfterCheck.java:        final String line = getLine(astLineNo - 1);  ```  Noticed in https://github.com/checkstyle/checkstyle/issues/10837 and https://github.com/checkstyle/checkstyle/issues/10920, any check where we use  `AbstractCheck#getLine()` (extracting a line of code from a source file) should be converted to using code points instead of characters. Now that Checkstyle supports Unicode in variable names and counts Unicode surrogate pairs correctly, we should make sure that all affected checks use code points instead of character arrays to ensure that we are indexing the correct character.
Added Exception Handling for file not found Exception

column3: Class or Interface type AST has incorrect position and confusing structure
column4: A class or interface type used in a variable definition creates an AST with incorrect column and/or line numbers and strange structure:  ```bash  ➜  src cat Test.java  ``` ```java  import java.lang.annotation.ElementType; import java.lang.annotation.Retention; import java.lang.annotation.RetentionPolicy; import java.lang.annotation.Target; import java.util.Map;  public class Test {     public static void main() {         TypeToken.TypeSet types = new TypeToken() {}.getTypes();         Map.@MyAnnotation Entry e;     }     static class TypeToken{         public TypeSet getTypes() {             return null;         }          public class TypeSet {         }     }     class Class3{} }  @Retention(RetentionPolicy.CLASS) @Target({ ElementType.TYPE_USE }) @interface MyAnnotation { }                                                                                                                                   ```  Output(extraneous output omitted):  ```bash  ➜  src java -jar checkstyle-8.44-all.jar -t Test.java ...     |       |--VARIABLE_DEF -> VARIABLE_DEF [9:8]     |       |   |--MODIFIERS -> MODIFIERS [9:8]     |       |   |--TYPE -> TYPE [9:8]     |       |   |   |--IDENT -> TypeToken [9:8]     |       |   |   `--TYPE_ARGUMENTS -> TYPE_ARGUMENTS [9:17]     |       |   |       |--GENERIC_START -> < [9:17]     |       |   |       |--TYPE_ARGUMENT -> TYPE_ARGUMENT [9:33] // type argument actually starts on column 17     |       |   |       |   `--DOT -> . [9:33]  // should not be nested in type arguments AST, should not be root of Class3 AST     |       |   |       |       |--IDENT -> Class3 [9:18]     |       |   |       |       |--TYPE_ARGUMENTS -> TYPE_ARGUMENTS [9:24]     |       |   |       |       |   |--GENERIC_START -> < [9:24]     |       |   |       |       |   |--TYPE_ARGUMENT -> TYPE_ARGUMENT [9:25]     |       |   |       |       |   |   `--IDENT -> String [9:25]     |       |   |       |       |   `--GENERIC_END -> > [9:31]     |       |   |       |       `--IDENT -> TypeSet [9:34]  // should not be nested in type arguments AST     |       |   |       `--GENERIC_END -> > [9:32]     |       |   |--IDENT -> types [9:42]     |       |   `--ASSIGN -> = [9:48] ...     |       |--VARIABLE_DEF -> VARIABLE_DEF [10:11]     |       |   |--MODIFIERS -> MODIFIERS [10:11]     |       |   |--TYPE -> TYPE [10:11]   // type(Map) actually begins on column 8     |       |   |   `--DOT -> . [10:11]     |       |   |       |--IDENT -> Map [10:8]     |       |   |       |--ANNOTATIONS -> ANNOTATIONS [10:12]     |       |   |       |   `--ANNOTATION -> ANNOTATION [10:12]     |       |   |       |       |--AT -> @ [10:12]     |       |   |       |       `--IDENT -> MyAnnotation [10:13]     |       |   |       `--IDENT -> Entry [10:26]     |       |   `--IDENT -> e [10:32]     |       |--SEMI -> ; [10:33]   ...  ```  Full AST can be found here: https://gist.github.com/nmancus1/73b4219c86eed420f18fd185e6893384  I would expect the AST to look like this:  ```bash ...     |       |--VARIABLE_DEF -> VARIABLE_DEF [9:8]     |       |   |--MODIFIERS -> MODIFIERS [9:8]     |       |   |--TYPE -> TYPE [9:8]     |       |   |   |--IDENT -> TypeToken [9:8]     |       |   |   `--TYPE_ARGUMENTS -> TYPE_ARGUMENTS [9:17] // correct position     |       |   |       |--GENERIC_START -> < [9:17]     |       |   |       |--TYPE_ARGUMENT -> TYPE_ARGUMENT [9:18]     |       |   |       |   |--IDENT -> Class3 [9:18]     |       |   |       |   |--TYPE_ARGUMENTS -> TYPE_ARGUMENTS [9:24]     |       |   |       |   |   |--GENERIC_START -> < [9:24]     |       |   |       |   |   |--TYPE_ARGUMENT -> TYPE_ARGUMENT [9:25]     |       |   |       |   |   |   `--IDENT -> String [9:25]     |       |   |       |   |   `--GENERIC_END -> > [9:31]     |       |   |       |   |--DOT -> . [9:33]     |       |   |       |   `--IDENT -> TypeSet [9:34]     |       |   |       `--GENERIC_END -> > [9:32] // can't be fixed until ANTLR4 update, but should be above the DOT at 9:33     |       |   |--IDENT -> types [9:42]     |       |   `--ASSIGN -> = [9:48] ...     |       |--VARIABLE_DEF -> VARIABLE_DEF [10:8]     |       |   |--MODIFIERS -> MODIFIERS [10:8]     |       |   |--TYPE -> TYPE [10:8]     |       |   |   |--IDENT -> Map [10:8]     |       |   |   |--DOT -> . [10:11]     |       |   |   |--ANNOTATIONS -> ANNOTATIONS [10:12]     |       |   |   |   `--ANNOTATION -> ANNOTATION [10:12]     |       |   |   |       |--AT -> @ [10:12]     |       |   |   |       `--IDENT -> MyAnnotation [10:13]     |       |   |   `--IDENT -> Entry [10:26]     |       |   `--IDENT -> e [10:32]     |       |--SEMI -> ; [10:33] ...  ```  Link to diff: https://www.diffchecker.com/U0zE8Dno  This can be fixed by removing the `^` ANTLR operator from the `DOT` token in the `classOrInterfaceType` production rule. While it is true that the `DOT` token is an operator in Java (and would arguably be the "root" of this AST), I think in the `classOrInterfaceType` production rule, where we have have three distinct elements (annotations, type parameters, and identifiers) it makes sense to have the `DOT` as a parallel element in respect to the `IDENT`s and `ANNOTATIONS`.

column3: Improve documentation about external DTD loading
column4: A clarification has been made in https://github.com/checkstyle/checkstyle/issues/10788:  > Checkstyle disallows the features by default in XMLs without that extra parameter: >  >     * load-external-dtd >     * external-general-entities >     * external-parameter-entities  I couldn't find the second and third limitations in the documentation, and specifically not in https://checkstyle.sourceforge.io/config_system_properties.html#Enable_External_DTD_load, since it's related to `checkstyle.enableExternalDtdLoad`. The documentation must be more explicit about this.

column3: MetadataGeneratorUtil doesn't support custom output folder locations
column4: `MetadataGeneratorUtil` doesn't allow any user configuration for where to place the meta files it generates. As such they go to the base `src\main\resources` folder, and doesn't allow a custom location like checkstyle has at `src\main\resources\com\puppycrawl\tools\checkstyle\meta`.  In addition, it doesn't allow any configuration to keep XML files separated into different folders like checkstyle has with `meta\checks\annotation` and `meta\checks\blocks` as an example.  We should expand this util to be just as configurable as checkstyle allows for itself.  See https://github.com/checkstyle/checkstyle/blob/13481f2c410e4944ecf5ab93ec49948a523a0c82/src/main/java/com/puppycrawl/tools/checkstyle/meta/XmlMetaWriter.java#L160-L178 as the targeted code which give checkstyle the extra functions others don't get.  The 2nd argument can be used for the output location, just like the first argument is for the input location. We may have to switch `MetadataGeneratorUtil` to picocli for it to take optional arguments.
`BeforeExecutionExclusionFileFilter` got added back into #10603 upon rebase: https://github.com/checkstyle/checkstyle/pull/10603/files . This PR removes it.

column3: UnusedImports error if there are only array references to a given class
column4: ```bash slovdahl@desk:~/checkstyle-unused-import-bug-reproducer/src/main/java (main)$ javac checkstyle/reproducer/UnusedImportBug.java  slovdahl@desk:~/checkstyle-unused-import-bug-reproducer/src/main/java (main)$   slovdahl@desk:~/checkstyle-unused-import-bug-reproducer (main)$ cat gradle/checkstyle/checkstyle.xml                                                 slovdahl@desk:~/checkstyle-unused-import-bug-reproducer (main)$ cat src/main/java/checkstyle/reproducer/UnusedImportBug.java  package checkstyle.reproducer;  import java.util.HashMap; import java.util.HashSet; import java.util.Set;  public class UnusedImportBug {      private static final Set FOO;     static {         FOO = new HashSet();          FOO.add( HashMap[].class.getName() );     } }   slovdahl@desk:~/checkstyle-unused-import-bug-reproducer (main)$ RUN_LOCALE="-Duser.language=en -Duser.country=US" slovdahl@desk:~/checkstyle-unused-import-bug-reproducer (main)$ java $RUN_LOCALE -jar checkstyle-9.0.1-all.jar -c gradle/checkstyle/checkstyle.xml src/main/java/checkstyle/reproducer/UnusedImportBug.java Starting audit... [ERROR] /home/slovdahl/checkstyle-unused-import-bug-reproducer/src/main/java/checkstyle/reproducer/UnusedImportBug.java:3:8: Unused import - java.util.HashMap. [UnusedImports] Audit done. Checkstyle ends with 1 errors.  ```  ---  **Describe what you expect in detail.**  The `UnusedImport` error should not be triggered if an import is actually used.  ---  MCVE: https://github.com/hiboxsystems/checkstyle-unused-import-bug-reproducer

column3: RequireEmptyLineBeforeBlockTagGroup gives error when theres a single trailing whitespace after asterisk
column4: ```bash /var/tmp $ javac Test.java  /var/tmp $ cat config.xml                 /var/tmp $ cat Test.java public class Test {   /**    * Place holder method    *     * @param string given string    */   public void placeholder(String string) {     // some logic   } }  /var/tmp $ java -jar checkstyle-9.0.1-all.jar -c config.xml Test.java Starting audit... [ERROR] /var/tmp/Test.java:6: Javadoc tag '@param' should be preceded with an empty line. [RequireEmptyLineBeforeBlockTagGroup] Audit done. Checkstyle ends with 1 errors. ```  ---  Expected that this should not give an error.  If you have one whitespace after the asterisk (*) on the preceding line of a BlockTagGroup, checkstyle gives an error stating the line is not empty. It will resolve itself if I remove the one trailing whitespace, but in the editor I use (VSC), when writing javadoc, it will automatically give a single whitespace after the asterisk when entering a new line. It is a bit annoying having to delete this one trailing whitespace everytime.  Hope you can take a look at this!  ---

column3: google_checks.xml: incorrect warnings for empty try with resources blocks
column4: ```bash $ java -jar checkstyle-8.45.1-all.jar -c /google_checks.xml T.java ... [WARN] T.java:3:31: Empty try block. [EmptyBlock] [WARN] T.java:3:31: WhitespaceAround: '{' is not followed by whitespace. Empty blocks may only be represented as {} when not part of a multi-block statement (4.1.3) [WhitespaceAround] [WARN] T.java:3:32: WhitespaceAround: '}' is not preceded with whitespace. [WhitespaceAround] ```  ```java class T {   {     try (Foo foo = new Foo()) {}   }    static class Foo implements AutoCloseable {     @Override     public void close() {}   } } ```  The Google Java Style Guide permits the above code, it should not result in a warning with `google_checks.xml`.  From https://google.github.io/styleguide/javaguide.html#s4.1.3-braces-empty-blocks  > An empty block or block-like construct ... may be closed immediately after it is opened, with no characters or line break in between (`{}`), unless it is part of a multi-block statement (one that directly contains multiple blocks: `if`/`else` or `try`/`catch`/`finally`).  The part about `try`/`catch`/`finally` doesn't apply to try with resources block without a `catch` or `finally` block.

```bash $ cd /tmp $ git clone git@github.com:jdbi/jdbi $ cd jdbi $ ./mvnw checkstyle:check [... check is successful ...] $ find . -name checkstyle-cachefile | xargs rm -f $ ./mvnw -Ddep.checkstyle.version=8.44 checkstyle:check [ERROR] /private/tmp/jdbi/core/src/main/java/org/jdbi/v3/core/mapper/MapEntryMapper.java:42:39: Array brackets at illegal position. [ArrayTypeStyle] [ERROR] /private/tmp/jdbi/core/src/main/java/org/jdbi/v3/core/generic/GenericTypes.java:35:33: Array brackets at illegal position. [ArrayTypeStyle] ``` ---  Expected: build still works fine with the ruleset we have been using for a long time. Actual result: see above  [ERROR] /private/tmp/jdbi/core/src/main/java/org/jdbi/v3/core/mapper/MapEntryMapper.java:42:39: Array brackets at illegal position. [ArrayTypeStyle] [ERROR] /private/tmp/jdbi/core/src/main/java/org/jdbi/v3/core/generic/GenericTypes.java:35:33: Array brackets at illegal position. [ArrayTypeStyle]  ---  This is a regression from 8.43 to 8.44. The offending lines:  ```java         TypeVariable[] mapParams = Map.Entry.class.getTypeParameters(); ```  ```java         TypeVariable[] mapParams = Map.class.getTypeParameters(); ```  My guess is that the code gets confused by the generic types for the arrays.

column3: The build shoul fail on Javadoc linter warnings
column4: ```bash $ cat TestClass.java ```  ```java public class TestClass {     /**      * Some desc.      *      * @return some value      * @throws Exception      * @return some other value      *       */     public int getValue() throws Exception {} } ```  ```bash $ javadoc TestClass.java Loading source file TestClass.java... Constructing Javadoc information... Building index for all the packages and classes... Standard Doclet version 16.0.1+9 Building tree for all the packages and classes... Generating ./TestClass.html... TestClass.java:14: warning: no description for @throws      * @throws Exception        ^ TestClass.java:15: warning: @return has already been specified      * @return some other value        ^ ```  These violations are warnings. The build passes if something similar is found. We should configure the build to fail on such violations.  _Originally posted by @rnveach in https://github.com/checkstyle/checkstyle/pull/10813#discussion_r714377756_

column3: Array declarator bracket placement in `TYPE_ARGUMENTS` AST is incorrect
column4: ```bash  ➜  src javac Test.java  ➜  src cat Test.java import java.lang.reflect.TypeVariable;  public class Test {     public TypeVariable[] getTypeParameters() {         return null;     } }  ➜  src java -jar checkstyle-8.43-all.jar -t Test.javav Files to process must be specified, found 0.  ➜  src java -jar checkstyle-8.44-SNAPSHOT-all.jar -t Test.java  IMPORT -> import [1:0] |--DOT -> . [1:24] |   |--DOT -> . [1:16] |   |   |--DOT -> . [1:11] |   |   |   |--IDENT -> java [1:7] |   |   |   `--IDENT -> lang [1:12] |   |   `--IDENT -> reflect [1:17] |   `--IDENT -> TypeVariable [1:25] `--SEMI -> ; [1:37] CLASS_DEF -> CLASS_DEF [3:0] |--MODIFIERS -> MODIFIERS [3:0] |   `--LITERAL_PUBLIC -> public [3:0] |--LITERAL_CLASS -> class [3:7] |--IDENT -> Test [3:13] `--OBJBLOCK -> OBJBLOCK [3:18]     |--LCURLY -> { [3:18]     |--METHOD_DEF -> METHOD_DEF [4:4]     |   |--MODIFIERS -> MODIFIERS [4:4]     |   |   `--LITERAL_PUBLIC -> public [4:4]     |   |--TYPE -> TYPE [4:11]     |   |   |--IDENT -> TypeVariable [4:11]     |   |   `--TYPE_ARGUMENTS -> TYPE_ARGUMENTS [4:23]     |   |       |--GENERIC_START -> < [4:23]     |   |       |--TYPE_ARGUMENT -> TYPE_ARGUMENT [4:24]     |   |       |   |--IDENT -> Class [4:24]     |   |       |   |--TYPE_ARGUMENTS -> TYPE_ARGUMENTS [4:29]     |   |       |   |   |--GENERIC_START -> < [4:29]     |   |       |   |   |--TYPE_ARGUMENT -> TYPE_ARGUMENT [4:30]     |   |       |   |   |   |--IDENT -> String [4:30]     |   |       |   |   |   `--ARRAY_DECLARATOR -> [ [4:36] // Correct     |   |       |   |   |       `--RBRACK -> ] [4:37]     |   |       |   |   `--GENERIC_END -> > [4:38]     |   |       |   `--ARRAY_DECLARATOR -> [ [4:40] // Incorrect     |   |       |       `--RBRACK -> ] [4:41]     |   |       `--GENERIC_END -> > [4:39]     |   |--IDENT -> getTypeParameters [4:43]     |   |--LPAREN -> ( [4:60]     |   |--PARAMETERS -> PARAMETERS [4:61]     |   |--RPAREN -> ) [4:61]     |   `--SLIST -> { [4:63]     |       |--LITERAL_RETURN -> return [5:8]     |       |   |--EXPR -> EXPR [5:15]     |       |   |   `--LITERAL_NULL -> null [5:15]     |       |   `--SEMI -> ; [5:19]     |       `--RCURLY -> } [6:4]     `--RCURLY -> } [7:0]   ```  The `[]` that follow the type arguments of the `getTypeParameters()` method are part of the return type of the method itself, and should be located in the method declaration's `TYPE` subtree. Example:  ```bash  IMPORT -> import [1:0] |--DOT -> . [1:24] |   |--DOT -> . [1:16] |   |   |--DOT -> . [1:11] |   |   |   |--IDENT -> java [1:7] |   |   |   `--IDENT -> lang [1:12] |   |   `--IDENT -> reflect [1:17] |   `--IDENT -> TypeVariable [1:25] `--SEMI -> ; [1:37] CLASS_DEF -> CLASS_DEF [3:0] |--MODIFIERS -> MODIFIERS [3:0] |   `--LITERAL_PUBLIC -> public [3:0] |--LITERAL_CLASS -> class [3:7] |--IDENT -> Test [3:13] `--OBJBLOCK -> OBJBLOCK [3:18]     |--LCURLY -> { [3:18]     |--METHOD_DEF -> METHOD_DEF [4:4]     |   |--MODIFIERS -> MODIFIERS [4:4]     |   |   `--LITERAL_PUBLIC -> public [4:4]     |   |--TYPE -> TYPE [4:11]     |   |   |--IDENT -> TypeVariable [4:11]     |   |   |--TYPE_ARGUMENTS -> TYPE_ARGUMENTS [4:23]     |   |   |   |--GENERIC_START -> < [4:23]     |   |   |   |--TYPE_ARGUMENT -> TYPE_ARGUMENT [4:24]     |   |   |   |   |--IDENT -> Class [4:24]     |   |   |   |   `--TYPE_ARGUMENTS -> TYPE_ARGUMENTS [4:29]     |   |   |   |       |--GENERIC_START -> < [4:29]     |   |   |   |       |--TYPE_ARGUMENT -> TYPE_ARGUMENT [4:30]     |   |   |   |       |   |--IDENT -> String [4:30]     |   |   |   |       |   `--ARRAY_DECLARATOR -> [ [4:36] // Correct     |   |   |   |       |       `--RBRACK -> ] [4:37]     |   |   |   |       `--GENERIC_END -> > [4:38]     |   |   |   `--GENERIC_END -> > [4:39]     |   |   `--ARRAY_DECLARATOR -> [ [4:40]     // Correct     |   |       `--RBRACK -> ] [4:41]                  |   |--IDENT -> getTypeParameters [4:43]     |   |--LPAREN -> ( [4:60]     |   |--PARAMETERS -> PARAMETERS [4:61]     |   |--RPAREN -> ) [4:61]     |   `--SLIST -> { [4:63]     |       |--LITERAL_RETURN -> return [5:8]     |       |   |--EXPR -> EXPR [5:15]     |       |   |   `--LITERAL_NULL -> null [5:15]     |       |   `--SEMI -> ; [5:19]     |       `--RCURLY -> } [6:4]     `--RCURLY -> } [7:0]  ```

```bash  ➜  src cat Test.java public class Test {     String aaaaaac = "  "; // two spaces     String aaaaaad = "💩💩"; // two emojis }  ➜  src java -jar checkstyle-8.43-all.jar -t Test.java CLASS_DEF -> CLASS_DEF [1:0] |--MODIFIERS -> MODIFIERS [1:0] |   `--LITERAL_PUBLIC -> public [1:0] |--LITERAL_CLASS -> class [1:7] |--IDENT -> Test [1:13] `--OBJBLOCK -> OBJBLOCK [1:18]     |--LCURLY -> { [1:18]     |--VARIABLE_DEF -> VARIABLE_DEF [2:4]     |   |--MODIFIERS -> MODIFIERS [2:4]     |   |--TYPE -> TYPE [2:4]     |   |   `--IDENT -> String [2:4]     |   |--IDENT -> aaaaaac [2:11]     |   |--ASSIGN -> = [2:19]     |   |   `--EXPR -> EXPR [2:21]     |   |       `--STRING_LITERAL -> "  " [2:21]     |   `--SEMI -> ; [2:25]     |--VARIABLE_DEF -> VARIABLE_DEF [3:4]     |   |--MODIFIERS -> MODIFIERS [3:4]     |   |--TYPE -> TYPE [3:4]     |   |   `--IDENT -> String [3:4]     |   |--IDENT -> aaaaaad [3:11]     |   |--ASSIGN -> = [3:19]     |   |   `--EXPR -> EXPR [3:21]     |   |       `--STRING_LITERAL -> "💩💩" [3:21]     |   `--SEMI -> ; [3:27]                          // should be 3:25     `--RCURLY -> } [4:0]  ➜  src while read line; do echo -n "$line" | wc -m ; done< Test.java   19 22 22 1  ```  I would expect the following:  ```bash  CLASS_DEF -> CLASS_DEF [1:0] |--MODIFIERS -> MODIFIERS [1:0] |   `--LITERAL_PUBLIC -> public [1:0] |--LITERAL_CLASS -> class [1:7] |--IDENT -> Test [1:13] `--OBJBLOCK -> OBJBLOCK [1:18]     |--LCURLY -> { [1:18]     |--VARIABLE_DEF -> VARIABLE_DEF [2:4]     |   |--MODIFIERS -> MODIFIERS [2:4]     |   |--TYPE -> TYPE [2:4]     |   |   `--IDENT -> String [2:4]     |   |--IDENT -> aaaaaac [2:11]     |   |--ASSIGN -> = [2:19]     |   |   `--EXPR -> EXPR [2:21]     |   |       `--STRING_LITERAL -> "  " [2:21]     |   `--SEMI -> ; [3:25]     `--RCURLY -> } [4:0]  ```

``` [INFO] PMD Failure: com.puppycrawl.tools.checkstyle.xpath.XpathQueryGeneratorTest:559 Rule:JUnit5TestShouldBePackagePrivate Priority:3 JUnit 5 tests should be package-private.. [ERROR] Failed to execute goal org.apache.maven.plugins:maven-pmd-plugin:3.14.0:check (default) on project checkstyle: You have 4488 PMD violations. ```  New rule [JUnit5TestShouldBePackagePrivate](https://pmd.github.io/pmd-6.35.0/pmd_rules_java_bestpractices.html#junit5testshouldbepackageprivate) requires that all tests should be like ```java     @Test     /* package */ void testGood() {     } ```  Another possibility is to remove just `public` modifier and disable [CommentDefaultAccessModifier](https://pmd.github.io/latest/pmd_rules_java_codestyle.html#commentdefaultaccessmodifier) for tests.  _Originally posted by @pbludov in https://github.com/checkstyle/checkstyle/issues/10055#issuecomment-851742376_

column3: FinalClass should exempt private-only constructor classes that are extended by another class in the same compilation unit
column4: ``` $ cat src/main/java/Main.java ``` ```java public final class Main {     private class SuperClass {         private SuperClass() {         }     }      private final class SubClass extends SuperClass {     } } ```  ``` $ cat checkstyle.xml  ``` ```xml                        ```  ``` $ cat pom.xml ``` ```xml     4.0.0   test   test   1.0-SNAPSHOT   test checkstyle        11     11                         org.apache.maven.plugins        maven-checkstyle-plugin        3.1.2                                       com.puppycrawl.tools               checkstyle               9.0.1                                          checkstyle.xml          UTF-8          true          true          false                                      validate            validate                          check                                              ```  ``` $ mvn clean install  [INFO] Scanning for projects... [INFO]  [INFO] -----------------------------< test:test >------------------------------ [INFO] Building test checkstyle 1.0-SNAPSHOT [INFO] --------------------------------[ jar ]--------------------------------- [INFO]  [INFO] --- maven-clean-plugin:2.5:clean (default-clean) @ test --- [INFO] Deleting /home/jean-noel/git/checkstyle/target [INFO]  [INFO] --- maven-checkstyle-plugin:3.1.2:check (validate) @ test --- [INFO] Starting audit... [ERROR] /home/jean-noel/git/checkstyle/src/main/java/Main.java:2:5: Class SuperClass should be declared as final. [FinalClass] Audit done. [INFO] ------------------------------------------------------------------------ [INFO] BUILD FAILURE [INFO] ------------------------------------------------------------------------ [INFO] Total time:  0.809 s [INFO] Finished at: 2021-10-12T12:08:27+02:00 [INFO] ------------------------------------------------------------------------ [ERROR] Failed to execute goal org.apache.maven.plugins:maven-checkstyle-plugin:3.1.2:check (validate) on project test: Failed during checkstyle execution: There is 1 error reported by Checkstyle 9.0.1 with checkstyle.xml ruleset. -> [Help 1] ... ``` Similarly to #9357, the `FinalClass` module is doing it's job correctly in that it's detecting a non-final class with only private constructor(s), but it's not smart enough to realize that in this situation, there is another class that extends it in the same java file. This is allowed because these classes are [nestmates](https://openjdk.java.net/jeps/181).  Following checkstyle advice would result in compilation failure.

column3: Violation on the closing parenthesis on a new line in an annotation array.
column4: *Issue first reported in https://github.com/checkstyle/checkstyle/issues/10020#issuecomment-893156100* *First analysis done by @Abhishek-kumar09 : https://github.com/checkstyle/checkstyle/issues/10020#issuecomment-895304847*  ----  Since the v8.45, Checkstyle reports a false positive error when you close an annotation parenthesis on a new line if you're in an array. This happens only in an array parameter of an annotation, not in a method body.  *AnnotationArray.java* ```java public class AnnotationArray {      @APIResponses({         // OK         @APIResponse(responseCode = "200", description = "Success"),         // OK         @APIResponse(             responseCode = "404",             description = "Not found"),         // KO         @APIResponse(             responseCode = "500",             description = "Internal error"         ) // Error is here (line 14)     })     public void get() {         // OK         var foo = List.of(             1,             2,             3         );         // OK         var bar = new Integer[]{             1,             2,             3         };     }      private static @interface APIResponse {         String responseCode();         String description();     }      private static @interface APIResponses {         APIResponse[] value() default {};     } } ```  *checkstyle.xml* ```xml                                                                                                                                                 ```  ```shell java -jar checkstyle-8.45-all.jar -c checkstyle.xml AnnotationArray.java ```  ``` Starting audit... [ERROR] /home/junior/Downloads/AnnotationArray.java:14:9: 'annotation array initialization' child has incorrect indentation level 8, expected level should be 12. [Indentation] Audit done. Checkstyle ends with 1 errors. ```

**How it works Now:**  My config: ``  My code: `if (criteria == null || criteria.isEmpty() || criteria.equals("{}")) {`  The checkstyle message: `String literal expressions should be on the left side of an equals comparison. [EqualsAvoidNull]`  **Is your feature request related to a problem? Please describe.**  The code is more readable with the line of code I've shown above.  **Describe the solution you'd like**  Instead of suppressing the warning, I'd like to request a feature request. I'd like `EqualsAvoidNull` to detect that the object is not null and not show me this warning.

**How it works Now:**  ```java import java.util.Optional;  public class TestClass {      public static void main(String... args){         var value = Optional.ofNullable(foo())                 .orElse(bar()); // violation Consider using "Optional.orElseGet"          value = Optional.ofNullable(foo())                 .orElseGet(() -> bar()); // OK          System.out.println(value);     }      static String foo() {         System.out.println("foo called");         return "foo";     }      static String bar() {         System.out.println("bar called");         return "bar";     }  } ```  ```bash /var/tmp $ java TestClass.java foo called bar called foo called foo ```  ----  The problem is that both methods were executed. And the result of the second call is just discarded (silently!). This may be not what the user expected. Today I spend some time to figure out a DB entity leak. It turns out that method `getOrCreate` was implemented as `Optional.ofNullable(getExisting()).orElse(creteNew())`. And it was creating a new entity on every call. Anyway, making some work and then just discard the result is a bad practice.  The solution is simple: replace `orElse(bar())` with `orElseGet(() -> bar())`. If the `orElse` part is required, then it should be extracted to a variable, like this:  ``` var first = foo();  // it is clear that both methods should be invoked var second = bar();  var value = Optional.ofNullable(first)                 .orElse(second); ```  The idea of new check is to verify that only constant values or variables are passed to `orElse(...)`.  All complicated stuff should be done in `orElseGet(() -> ...)`   A good article for this issue: https://www.baeldung.com/java-optional-or-else-vs-or-else-get

**How it works Now:**  ```bash [INFO] --- maven-checkstyle-plugin:3.1.2:checkstyle (default-cli) @ project --- [INFO] Starting audit... ... other checkstyle output ... Audit done. [INFO]  ```  **Desired output** ```bash [INFO] --- maven-checkstyle-plugin:3.1.2:checkstyle (default-cli) @ project --- [INFO] Starting audit... ... other non-indented checkstyle output is okay ... [INFO] Audit done. [INFO]  ```  **So that the output is aligned when there are no violations** ```bash [INFO] --- maven-checkstyle-plugin:3.1.2:checkstyle (default-cli) @ project --- [INFO] Starting audit... [INFO] Audit done. [INFO]  ```  **Similar to SpotBugs and PMD output** ```bash [INFO] --- spotbugs-maven-plugin:4.3.0:spotbugs (spotbugs) @ project --- [INFO] Fork Value is true [INFO] Done SpotBugs Analysis.... [INFO]  [INFO] --- maven-pmd-plugin:3.14.0:check (default-cli) @ project --- [INFO] PMD version: 6.37.0 [INFO]  ```

column3: SevNTU is no longer available in Eclipse
column4: **Describe what you expect in detail.**  I'm using the latest Eclipse 2021-06. I installed/updated to the latest Checkstyle plugin which upgraded me from 8.35 to 8.44.  The sevntu checks were available when I used 8.35.  After the upgrade, the sevntu checks have disappeared from the configuration screen. If I make any changes to other checks, the XML file is modified and the sevntu checks are removed.  If I search through the available update sites, the sevntu plugin is not found. If I uninstall and reinstall Checkstyle, it doesn't resolve.  Everything however works fine if I stick with my Maven setup for 8.44 + 1.40.0

column3: MissingSwitchDefault applied to switch expressions that return nothing
column4: > I have read check documentation: https://checkstyle.org/config_xxxxxx.html#NameOfAffectedCheck  The above link as https://checkstyle.org/config_xxxxxx.html#MissingSwitchDefault is not found on my browser.  > I have downloaded the latest checkstyle from: https://checkstyle.org/cmdline.html#Download_and_Run  Yes.  > I have executed the cli and showed it below, as cli describes the problem better than 1,000 words  ```bash  [~/Downloads] [21:39:31] >> cat Sample.java  /**  * Useless Javadoc.  */ public class Sample {   private enum Options {     ONE,     TWO,     THREE   }    private int error(Options option) {     switch (option) { // line 12: checkstyle violation       case ONE: return 1;       case TWO: return 2;       case THREE: return 3;     }      return 0;   }    private int ok1(Options option) {     return switch (option) { // ok       case ONE -> 1;       case TWO -> 2;       case THREE -> 3;     };   }    private int ok2(Options option) {     switch (option) { // line 30: should be ok       case ONE -> System.out.println("1");       case TWO -> System.out.println("2");       case THREE -> System.out.println("3");     };     return 0;   } } ```  ```bash  [~/Downloads] [21:42:53] >> java -version openjdk version "16.0.2" 2021-07-20 OpenJDK Runtime Environment Temurin-16.0.2+7 (build 16.0.2+7) OpenJDK 64-Bit Server VM Temurin-16.0.2+7 (build 16.0.2+7, mixed mode, sharing)   [~/Downloads] [21:43:05] >> javac -verbose Sample.java 2>&1 | grep -v loading [parsing started SimpleFileObject[/Users/snaran/Downloads/Sample.java]] [parsing completed 16ms] [search path for source files: .] [search path for class files: /Library/Java/JavaVirtualMachines/temurin-16.jdk/Contents/Home/lib/modules,.] [checking Sample] [wrote Sample$Options.class] [wrote Sample$1.class] [wrote Sample.class] [total 234ms]   [~/Downloads] [21:43:10] >> java -jar checkstyle-9.0-all.jar -c /google_checks.xml Sample.java Starting audit... [WARN] /Users/snaran/Downloads/Sample.java:12:5: switch without "default" clause. [MissingSwitchDefault] [WARN] /Users/snaran/Downloads/Sample.java:30:5: switch without "default" clause. [MissingSwitchDefault] Audit done. ```  ---  If a switch is a switch expression, then MissingSwitchDefault should not be applied, even if the switch expression does not return anything, as the compiler enforces that the switch is exhaustive.  It looks like checkstyle does not enforce the check for a switch expression that returns something (see ok1), but enforces check for a switch expression that does something.

> By change the visibility to private there is 12 errors and 29 warnings.  I think we should create a new issue for changing to private. We are already particular on our Javadocs from our checks. It would make sense we do the same with any other tool as long as it doesn't damage us.  _Originally posted by @rnveach in https://github.com/checkstyle/checkstyle/issues/10816#issuecomment-925932655_

column3: Checkstyle should force logging of AST in checks that require it
column4: > @pbludov should we somehow limit the usage of "old" `log` method to help prevent this is in the future?  This is a good idea. Developers should be aware of this. We have a [check](https://github.com/checkstyle/checkstyle/blob/38df63e992c1270eac87d5e98d5d8cb281c4a20b/config/checkstyle_sevntu_checks.xml#L215) to forbid some method by its name and number of parameters.   Unfortunately, the "old" `log` method is still used by Javadoc checks and filters. See #4830 for the details. This means we should add an entry for `ForbidCertainMethodCheck` and suppress this violation for `*Flter` and `Javadoc*Check`.  _Originally posted by @pbludov in https://github.com/checkstyle/checkstyle/issues/10930#issuecomment-962656895_  -----------------  Confusion between `AbstractCheck#log` methods, as noticed in https://github.com/checkstyle/checkstyle/pull/10930#issuecomment-962656895, can be difficult for contributors to troubleshoot when `XPathRegression...` tests are failing due to suppressions not functioning as expected. It might be a good idea to add some sort of warning about this to the documentation for `AbstractViolationReporter#log` as well. Perhaps we could extend the current summary (`Log a message that has no column information.`) to something like `Log a message that has no column information. Usage of this log method should be restricted to FileSet checks, Javadoc checks, and filters.`

column3: Create JUnit extension for unit tests requiring limited resources
column4: > @nmancus1, I have an idea. We can write JUnit extension for this. A test will be something like that:  ```java     @Test     @Timeout(value = 10, unit = TimeUnit.SECONDS)     @Thread(name = "DeepStringConcat", stackSize = 147456)     public void testNoStackOverflowOnDeepStringConcat() throws Exception {         final File file =                 new File(getPath("InputJavaParserNoStackOverflowOnDeepStringConcat.java"));         final DetailAST ast = JavaParser.parseFile(file, JavaParser.Options.WITH_COMMENTS);          assertWithMessage("File parsing should complete successfully.")                 .that(ast)                 .isNotNull();     } ``` > The extension `@Timeout` is build-in in JUnit. The extension `@Thread` can be implemented as an `InvocationInterceptor` like [this one](https://github.com/junit-team/junit5/blob/main/documentation/src/test/java/example/interceptor/SwingEdtInterceptor.java)  > Here is some documentation: https://github.com/junit-team/junit5/blob/main/documentation/src/docs/asciidoc/user-guide/extensions.adoc#extensions-intercepting-invocations  _Originally posted by @pbludov in https://github.com/checkstyle/checkstyle/pull/10640#discussion_r693499928_  Here is @pbludov 's attempt: https://github.com/checkstyle/checkstyle/commit/d78f311a2ade3fac24225cad509ee0e2f5527422

### reworks JavadocMetadataScrapperTest to make more sense  Moved all tests related to `JavadocMetadataScrapper` into `JavadocMetadataScrapperTest` and use BDD and actually verify outputs from the check. Hopefully, at some point we can use pitest and such on this class to verify it's code.  ### changes InlineConfigParser to respect fully qualified name   This is a simple change to so that when it gets the fully qualified name, it takes as the fully qualified name and doesn't make any other changes. This is all because `JavadocMetadataScrapper` doesn't end with `Check` so BDD can't recognize it. No idea why the class was named this, but BDD should still be changed as I expect the FQN to be the FQN.

column3: A lot of translations should be reviewed.
column4: ### Bug description  There is a lot of translations that are messed up, some of them to the point that some supposedly translated message becomes a meaningless gibberish or just plainly wrong and misleading. For example, the Portuguese message "_As tags de bloco devem aparecer no pedido ''{0}''._" made my eyes hurt, because "pedido" is as a translation for "order" only in the sense of ordering a pizza or a hamburguer somewhere instead of defining the order of javadoc tags.  Also, there is mojibake like "_KlasÃ¶r deseni ''{0}'' ve dosya deseni ` eÅŸleÅŸmiyor Dosya ''{1}''._"  Even sometimes, the English messages could be improved. For example, "_Control variable ''{0}'' is modified._" can be improved to "_The control variable ''{0}'' should not be modified._".  Further, some messages ends with periods, some others don't. They all should be standardized by ending with a period (or "。" for Japanese and Chinese). The exceptions to this rule should have a good and strong reason for not doing that.  ### Remarks  I am opening several bug reports with the intention of referencing them into a pull request very soon.  Personally, I speak Portuguese natively and also speak English [and contributed with some translations four years ago](https://github.com/checkstyle/checkstyle/pull/5082). I also can speak some Spanish and French nowadays, but not very fluently. So, I reviewed everything in those languages. Further, although I don't speak Turkish, German, Finnish, Japanese or Chinese, I also tried to fix a few cases on those languages that I suspected were broken or could be mecanically fixed.

column3: Fix up and refactor localization limitations.
column4: ## Bug description  There are a few internal problems about localization. I will enumerate them here:  1. There are two bundle caches. One in the `Violation` class and another one in the inner class `LocalizedMessage` inside the `DefaultLogger` class. They should be unified. 2. There is a lot of code duplication between the `AbstractCheck` and `AbstractFileSetCheck` that could be moved up to their common superclass `AbstractViolationReporter` with minimal risk of compatibility breakage. The class `OuterTypeFilenameCheck` might also be involved. 3. There is some tests that verify if the given message is exact. So, any change to the `message.properties` file makes those test break spuriously. This is not desirable. 4. Although the `Locale` should be setwith `-Duser.language=en -Duser.country=US` when running the tests in order to "officially" validate the build, it is highly desirable that the tests runs, works and passes anyway regardless of the user language, even if "unofficially". 5. The `Violation` class features a bunch of constructors and don't impose strong nullability contract about its fields. Usage of static builder methods instead of multiple overload constructors are preferable and the public constructors should be deprecated. Stronger nullability contracts should be imposed when possible. 6. The `Violation` class is intended to be immutable. But its `equals(Object)` method depends on `getViolation()` which depends on the current encoding. Also, `getViolation()` is not used as part of `hashCode()` or `compareTo(Violation)`. This is a fragile behaviour. 7. The `Violation.getViolation()` method repeatedly consults the `ResourceBundle` to build its message and the output might change if the `Locale` changes. Although this seems to be interesting, in practice, it has essentially no value since outside of unit tests, the `Locale` very rarely changes if ever. It would be better to set the message in the construction time and a change to the `Locale` should not retroactively change messages already produced because it is not worth the trouble. 8. Sometimes, changing the `Locale`, specially in unit tests, will produce incorrect results. This happens because the `Locale` is read and stored in different places at different moments. So, changing the `Locale` late, after everything was already initialized don't reliably works. There should be a single one centralized place for the `Locale`. 9. The `AbstractModuleTestSupport` class assumes that each line in the output maps to exactly a single violation. This doesn't hold if some error message contains a line break, which is specially true if the message features a Stack Trace, which is sometimes the case of `"general.exception"`.  ## Remarks  I am opening several bug reports with the intention of referencing them into a pull request very soon.  I could also open separate bugs for all of the above, but I think that it would be an overkill and only one bug report suffices.

# PLEASE READ before removing  Rules: 1) The issue you are trying to fix/resolve has to have the "approved" label. 2) Put in the description of Pull Request the reference to an issue if it exists.    Example: "Issue: #XXXXXX" 3) Commit message should adhere to the following rules:    a) MUST match one of the following patterns:       ^Issue #\\d+: .*$       ^Pull #\\d+: .*$       ^(minor|config|infra|doc|spelling|dependency): .*$    b) MUST contain only one line of text    c) MUST NOT end with a period, space, or tab    d) MUST be less than or equal to 200 characters  To avoid multiple iterations of fixes and CIs failures, please read https://checkstyle.org/contributing.html  ATTENTION: We are not merging Pull Requests that are not passing our CIs, but we will help to resolve issues.  Thanks for reading, remove whole this message and type what you need.
